chunk: There are 5 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts. Their names are as follows: * RC Scripts * Logon Script (Windows) * Network Logon Script * Startup Items * Login Hook The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts Attack technique description: Adversaries may use scripts automatically executed at boot or logon initialization to establish persistence.(Citation: Mandiant APT29 Eye Spy Email Nov 22)(Citation: Anomali Rocke March 2019) Initialization scripts can be used to perform administrative functions, which may often execute other programs or send information to an internal logging server. These scripts can vary based on operating system and whether applied locally or remotely. Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a single system. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. An adversary may also be able to escalate their privileges since some boot or logon initialization scripts run with higher privileges. Platforms: macOS, Windows, Linux, Network Attack technique name: RC Scripts Attack technique description: Adversaries may establish persistence by modifying RC scripts which are executed during a Unix-like system’s startup. These files allow system administrators to map and start custom services at startup for different run levels. RC scripts require root privileges to modify. Adversaries can establish persistence by adding a malicious binary path or shell commands to rc.local, rc.common, and other RC scripts specific to the Unix-like distribution.(Citation: IranThreats Kittens Dec 2017)(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019) Upon reboot, the system executes the script's contents as root, resulting in persistence. Adversary abuse of RC scripts is especially effective for lightweight Unix-like distributions using the root user as default, such as IoT or embedded systems.(Citation: intezer-kaiji-malware) Several Unix-like systems have moved to Systemd and deprecated the use of RC scripts. This is now a deprecated mechanism in macOS in favor of [Launchd](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053/004). (Citation: Apple Developer Doco Archive Launchd)(Citation: Startup Items) This technique can be used on Mac OS X Panther v10.3 and earlier versions which still execute the RC scripts.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) To maintain backwards compatibility some systems, such as Ubuntu, will execute the RC scripts if they exist with the correct file permissions.(Citation: Ubuntu Manpage systemd rc) Platforms: macOS, Linux, Network Attack technique name: Logon Script (Windows) Attack technique description: Adversaries may use Windows logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Windows allows logon scripts to be run whenever a specific user or group of users log into a system.(Citation: TechNet Logon Scripts) This is done via adding a path to a script to the HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript Registry key.(Citation: Hexacorn Logon Scripts) Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a single system. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Network Logon Script Attack technique description: Adversaries may use network logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Network logon scripts can be assigned using Active Directory or Group Policy Objects.(Citation: Petri Logon Script AD) These logon scripts run with the privileges of the user they are assigned to. Depending on the systems within the network, initializing one of these scripts could apply to more than one or potentially all systems. Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a network. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Startup Items Attack technique description: Adversaries may use startup items automatically executed at boot initialization to establish persistence. Startup items execute during the final phase of the boot process and contain shell scripts or other executable files along with configuration information used by the system to determine the execution order for all startup items.(Citation: Startup Items) This is technically a deprecated technology (superseded by [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004)), and thus the appropriate folder, /Library/StartupItems isn’t guaranteed to exist on the system by default, but does appear to exist by default on macOS Sierra. A startup item is a directory whose executable and configuration property list (plist), StartupParameters.plist, reside in the top-level directory. An adversary can create the appropriate folders/files in the StartupItems directory to register their own persistence mechanism.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) Additionally, since StartupItems run during the bootup phase of macOS, they will run as the elevated root user. Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: Login Hook Attack technique description: Adversaries may use a Login Hook to establish persistence executed upon user logon. A login hook is a plist file that points to a specific script to execute with root privileges upon user logon. The plist file is located in the /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist file and can be modified using the <

entities.name: BOOT OR LOGON INITIALIZATION SCRIPTS
entities.description: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts is an attack technique where adversaries use scripts executed at boot or logon to establish persistence on a system.

entities.name: RC SCRIPTS
entities.description: RC Scripts are an attack technique that allows adversaries to modify scripts executed during a Unix-like system's startup to establish persistence.

entities.name: LOGON SCRIPT (WINDOWS)
entities.description: Logon Script (Windows) is an attack technique where adversaries use Windows logon scripts to maintain persistence during user logon.

entities.name: NETWORK LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Network Logon Script is an attack technique that allows adversaries to use network logon scripts to establish persistence across multiple systems in a network.

entities.name: STARTUP ITEMS
entities.description: Startup Items is an attack technique where adversaries use items executed at boot initialization to maintain persistence on macOS systems.

entities.name: LOGIN HOOK
entities.description: Login Hook is an attack technique that allows adversaries to execute a specific script with root privileges upon user logon to establish persistence.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a series of operating systems developed by Microsoft, which is targeted by various attack techniques for establishing persistence.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is a family of open-source Unix-like operating systems, which is targeted by various attack techniques for establishing persistence.

Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: Login Hook Attack technique description: Adversaries may use a Login Hook to establish persistence executed upon user logon. A login hook is a plist file that points to a specific script to execute with root privileges upon user logon. The plist file is located in the /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist file and can be modified using the defaults command-line utility. This behavior is the same for logout hooks where a script can be executed upon user logout. All hooks require administrator permissions to modify or create hooks.(Citation: Login Scripts Apple Dev)(Citation: LoginWindowScripts Apple Dev) Adversaries can add or insert a path to a malicious script in the com.apple.loginwindow.plist file, using the LoginHook or LogoutHook key-value pair. The malicious script is executed upon the next user login. If a login hook already exists, adversaries can add additional commands to an existing login hook. There can be only one login and logout hook on a system at a time.(Citation: S1 macOs Persistence)(Citation: Wardle Persistence Chapter) **Note:** Login hooks were deprecated in 10.11 version of macOS in favor of [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004) and [Launch Agent](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/001) Platforms: macOS

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. for Macintosh computers, known for its user-friendly interface and robust security features.

entities.name: LOGIN HOOK
entities.description: Login Hook is an attack technique that allows adversaries to establish persistence by executing a script with root privileges upon user logon.

entities.name: LOGOUT HOOK
entities.description: Logout Hook is similar to Login Hook, allowing scripts to be executed upon user logout, requiring administrator permissions to modify.

entities.name: APPLE INC.
entities.description: Apple Inc. is a multinational technology company that designs, manufactures, and sells consumer electronics, computer software, and online services, including macOS.

entities.name: DEFAULTS COMMAND-LINE UTILITY
entities.description: The defaults command-line utility is a tool in macOS that allows users to read and write user defaults from the command line, enabling modifications to plist files.

entities.name: ADMINISTRATOR PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Administrator permissions are required to modify or create hooks in macOS, ensuring that only authorized users can make significant changes to system settings.

entities.name: LAUNCH DAEMON
entities.description: Launch Daemon is a macOS feature that allows scripts and applications to run in the background at system startup or at specified intervals, replacing deprecated login hooks.

entities.name: LAUNCH AGENT
entities.description: Launch Agent is a macOS feature that allows scripts and applications to run in the background when a user logs in, providing a more flexible alternative to login hooks.

There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Login Hook. Their names are as follows:
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting directory and file permissions to limit access, enhancing security against attacks like Login Hook.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called VNC. Their names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Audit 
* Limit Software Installation 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

entities.name: VNC
entities.description: VNC is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods to prevent unauthorized access and exploitation.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: This mitigation method involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: This mitigation method uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering, configuring software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: This mitigation method involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: This mitigation method blocks users or groups from installing unapproved software to enhance security.

entities.name: DHCP SPOOFING
entities.description: DHCP Spoofing is an attack technique that exploits the DHCP protocol to intercept network traffic and potentially redirect users to malicious sites.

entities.description: Platforms are the environments or systems on which software operates, including operating systems and hardware configurations.

entities.description: Software name is a placeholder representing the title of a specific software application, which is typically used to identify it in the market.

entities.description: Software information refers to the collective details about a software application, including its name, description, and platforms.

entities.name: ATTACK TECHNIQUE
entities.description: An attack technique is a method used by cyber attackers to exploit vulnerabilities in systems or networks, such as DHCP Spoofing.

entities.name: DYNAMIC HOST CONFIGURATION PROTOCOL (DHCP)
entities.description: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is a network management protocol used to automate the process of configuring devices on IP networks.

entities.name: NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Network traffic refers to the data that is transmitted over a network, which can be intercepted or manipulated during an attack.

entities.name: MALICIOUS SITES
entities.description: Malicious sites are websites designed to harm users or systems, often used in phishing attacks or to distribute malware.

* Restrict Registry Permissions 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: RESTRICT REGISTRY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict Registry Permissions is a mitigation method that limits the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry to enhance security against attacks.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies or techniques used to reduce the risk or impact of security threats, such as the attack techniques mentioned.

chunk:
There are 6 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called ARP Cache Poisoning. Their names are as follows:
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* User Training 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Filter Network Traffic 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: ARP CACHE POISONING
entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is an attack technique that exploits vulnerabilities in the Address Resolution Protocol to redirect network traffic and potentially intercept sensitive information.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information using strong encryption techniques to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that employs intrusion detection signatures to block malicious traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method aimed at educating users about security threats to reduce the risk of successful attacks such as spearphishing and social engineering.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary software to prevent exploitation by adversaries.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a mitigation method that restricts access to file shares and remote systems to enhance security.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter incoming and outgoing traffic based on protocols to enhance security.

Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: PcShare
Software description: [PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) is an open source remote access tool that has been modified and used by Chinese threat actors, most notably during the FunnyDream campaign since late 2018.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)(Citation: GitHub PcShare 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified

chunk:
, macOS, Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Brute Ratel C4
Software description: [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool that first appeared in December 2020. [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was specifically designed to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) capabilities, and deploys agents called badgers to enable arbitrary command execution for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and persistence. In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July 2022)(Citation: MDSec Brute Ratel August 2022)(Citation: SANS Brute Ratel October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Black Basta October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sliver
Software description: [Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) is an open source, cross-platform, red team command and control framework written in Golang.(Citation: Bishop Fox Sliver Framework August 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Remcos
Software description: [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) is a closed-source tool that is marketed as a remote control and surveillance software by a company called Breaking Security. [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has been observed being used in malware campaigns.(Citation: Riskiq Remcos Jan 2018)(Citation: Talos Remcos Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ConnectWise
Software description: [ConnectWise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0591) is a legitimate remote administration tool that has been used since at least 2016 by threat actors including [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) and [GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) to connect to and conduct lateral movement in target environments.(Citation: Anomali Static Kitten February 2021)(Citation: Trend Micro Muddy Water March 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RemoteUtilities
Software description: [RemoteUtilities](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0592) is a legitimate remote administration tool that has been used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) since at least 2021 for execution on target machines.(Citation: Trend Micro Muddy Water March 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AsyncRAT
Software description: [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087) is an open-source remote access tool originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository that has been used in malicious campaigns.(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Cisco Operation Layover September 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pteranodon
Software description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) is a custom backdoor used by [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047). (Citation: Palo Alto Gamaredon Feb 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GRIFFON
Software description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) is a JavaScript backdoor used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046). (Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: JHUHUGIT
Software description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation:

entities.description: Brute Ratel C4 is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool designed to avoid detection by EDR and AV capabilities, first appearing in December 2020.

entities.description: PowerSploit is an open source offensive security framework comprised of PowerShell modules and scripts for penetration testing.

entities.name: SLIVER
entities.description: Sliver is an open source, cross-platform red team command and control framework written in Golang.

entities.name: REMCO
entities.description: Remcos is a closed-source remote control and surveillance software marketed by Breaking Security, observed in malware campaigns.

entities.description: ConnectWise is a legitimate remote administration tool used by threat actors including MuddyWater and GOLD SOUTHFIELD since at least 2016.

entities.name: REMOTEUTILITIES
entities.description: RemoteUtilities is a legitimate remote administration tool used by MuddyWater since at least 2021 for execution on target machines.

entities.description: AsyncRAT is an open-source remote access tool used in malicious campaigns, originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository.

entities.description: Gamaredon Group is a cyber threat group known for using custom backdoors like Pteranodon in their operations.

entities.name: FIN7
entities.description: FIN7 is a cybercriminal group that employs backdoors like GRIFFON for their malicious activities.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a Russian cyber espionage group known for using malware like JHUHUGIT for reconnaissance purposes.

chunk:
JHUHUGIT
Software description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Agent Tesla
Software description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) is a spyware Trojan written for the .NET framework that has been observed since at least 2014.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TURNEDUP
Software description: [TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is a non-public backdoor. It has been dropped by [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064)'s [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) malware. (Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017) (Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Trojan.Karagany
Software description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) is a modular remote access tool used for recon and linked to [Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035). The source code for [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) originated from Dream Loader malware which was leaked in 2010 and sold on underground forums. (Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)(Citation: Secureworks Karagany July 2019)(Citation: Dragos DYMALLOY )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FinFisher
Software description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware reportedly sold exclusively to government agencies for use in targeted and lawful criminal investigations. It is heavily obfuscated and uses multiple anti-analysis techniques. It has other variants including [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176). (Citation: FinFisher Citation) (Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21) (Citation: FireEye FinSpy Sept 2017) (Citation: Securelist BlackOasis Oct 2017) (Citation: Microsoft FinFisher March 2018)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: Cobian RAT
Software description: [Cobian RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0338) is a backdoor, remote access tool that has been observed since 2016.(Citation: Zscaler Cobian Aug 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BADNEWS
Software description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is malware that has been used by the actors responsible for the [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) campaign. Its name was given due to its use of RSS feeds, forums, and blogs for command and control. (Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon) (Citation: TrendMicro Patchwork Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ramsay
Software description: [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) is an information stealing malware framework designed to collect and exfiltrate sensitive documents, including from air-gapped systems. Researchers have identified overlaps between [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) and the [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012)-associated Retro malware.(Citation: Eset Ramsay May 2020)(Citation: Antiy CERT Ramsay April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BlackEnergy
Software description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) is a malware toolkit that has been used by both criminal and APT actors. It dates back to at least 2007 and was originally designed to create botnets for use in conducting Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, but its use has evolved to support various plug-ins. It is well known for being used during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008, as well as in targeting Ukrainian institutions. Variants include BlackEnergy 2 and BlackEnergy 3. (Citation: F-Secure BlackEnergy 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Carbanak
Software description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) is a full-featured, remote backdoor used by a group of the same name ([Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008)). It is intended for espionage, data exfiltration, and providing remote access to infected machines. (Citation: Kaspersky Carbanak) (Citation: FireEye CARBANAK June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ObliqueRAT
Software description: [ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) is a remote access trojan, similar to [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115), that has been in use by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2020

Platforms: Windows

Software name: ObliqueRAT
Software description: [ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) is a remote access trojan, similar to [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115), that has been in use by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2020.(Citation: Talos Oblique RAT March 2021)(Citation: Talos Transparent Tribe May 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Clambling
Software description: [Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) is a modular backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2017.(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mispadu
Software description: [Mispadu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1122) is a banking trojan written in Delphi that was first observed in 2019 and uses a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) business model.(Citation: ESET Security Mispadu Facebook Ads 2019)(Citation: SCILabs Malteiro 2021) This malware is operated, managed, and sold by the [Malteiro](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1026) cybercriminal group.(Citation: SCILabs Malteiro 2021) [Mispadu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1122) has mainly been used to target victims in Brazil and Mexico, and has also had confirmed operations throughout Latin America and Europe.(Citation: SCILabs Malteiro 2021)(Citation: SCILabs URSA/Mispadu Evolution 2023)(Citation: Segurança Informática URSA Sophisticated Loader 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CrossRAT
Software description: [CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) is a cross platform RAT.
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: Prikormka
Software description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) is a malware family used in a campaign known as Operation Groundbait. It has predominantly been observed in Ukraine and was used as early as 2008. (Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BISCUIT
Software description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) is a backdoor that has been used by [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) since as early as 2007. (Citation: Mandiant APT1)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MacMa
Software description: [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) is a macOS-based backdoor with a large set of functionalities to control and exfiltrate files from a compromised computer. [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) has been observed in the wild since November 2021.(Citation: ESET DazzleSpy Jan 2022)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: BADHATCH
Software description: [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) is a backdoor that has been utilized by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) since at least 2019. [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) has been used to target the insurance, retail, technology, and chemical industries in the United States, Canada, South Africa, Panama, and Italy.(Citation: Gigamon BADHATCH Jul 2019)(Citation: BitDefender BADHATCH Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: njRAT
Software description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first observed in 2012. It has been used by threat actors in the Middle East.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Turian
Software description: [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is a backdoor that has been used by [BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) to target Ministries of Foreign Affairs, telecommunication companies, and charities in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. First reported in 2021, [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is likely related to Quarian, an older backdoor that was last observed being used in 2013 against diplomatic targets in Syria and the United States.(Citation: ESET BackdoorDiplomacy Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: Cannon
Software description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi. It was first observed in April 2018. (Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zebrocy
Software description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) is a Trojan that has been used by [APT28](https://attack

entities.description: Clambling is a modular backdoor written in C++ used by Threat Group-3390 since at least 2017, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: THREAT GROUP-3390
entities.description: Threat Group-3390 is a cybercriminal group that has been using Clambling since at least 2017.

entities.name: MISPADU
entities.description: Mispadu is a banking trojan first observed in 2019, operated by the Malteiro cybercriminal group, targeting victims in Brazil and Mexico.

entities.name: MALTEIRO
entities.description: Malteiro is a cybercriminal group that operates, manages, and sells the Mispadu banking trojan.

entities.name: CROSSRAT
entities.description: CrossRAT is a cross-platform remote access trojan that operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

entities.name: PRIKORMKA
entities.description: Prikormka is a malware family used in Operation Groundbait, predominantly observed in Ukraine since 2008.

entities.name: BISCUIT
entities.description: BISCUIT is a backdoor used by APT1 since as early as 2007, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: APT1
entities.description: APT1 is a cyber espionage group that has been using the BISCUIT backdoor since at least 2007.

entities.name: MACMA
entities.description: MacMa is a macOS-based backdoor observed in the wild since November 2021, with functionalities to control and exfiltrate files.

entities.name: BADHATCH
entities.description: BADHATCH is a backdoor utilized by FIN8 since at least 2019, targeting various industries in multiple countries.

entities.name: FIN8
entities.description: FIN8 is a cybercriminal group that has been using the BADHATCH backdoor to target industries in the United States, Canada, and other countries.

entities.name: NJRAT
entities.description: njRAT is a remote access tool first observed in 2012, used by threat actors in the Middle East.

entities.name: TURIAN
entities.description: Turian is a backdoor used by BackdoorDiplomacy to target Ministries of Foreign Affairs and other entities in various regions since 2021.

entities.name: BACKDOORDIPLOMACY
entities.description: BackdoorDiplomacy is a cybercriminal group that has been using the Turian backdoor to target diplomatic entities.

entities.name: CANNON
entities.description: Cannon is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi, first observed in April 2018.

entities.name: ZEBROCY
entities.description: Zebrocy is a Trojan used by APT28, a cyber espionage group.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform on which CrossRAT has been observed to operate.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform on which MacMa has been observed to operate.

entities.name: BRAZIL
entities.description: Brazil is a country that has been targeted by the Mispadu banking trojan.

entities.name: MEXICO
entities.description: Mexico is a country that has been targeted by the Mispadu banking trojan.

entities.name: LATIN AMERICA
entities.description: Latin America is a region where Mispadu has had confirmed operations.

entities.name: EUROPE
entities.description: Europe is a region where Mispadu has had confirmed operations.

chunk:
.org/software/S0351) is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi. It was first observed in April 2018. (Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zebrocy
Software description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) is a Trojan that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least November 2015. The malware comes in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, AutoIt, C#, VB.NET, and Golang. (Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: CISA Zebrocy Oct 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TajMahal
Software description: [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is a multifunctional spying framework that has been in use since at least 2014. [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is comprised of two separate packages, named Tokyo and Yokohama, and can deploy up to 80 plugins.(Citation: Kaspersky TajMahal April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: SharpStage
Software description: [SharpStage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0546) is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.(Citation: Cybereason Molerats Dec 2020)(Citation: BleepingComputer Molerats Dec 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: InvisiMole
Software description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) is a modular spyware program that has been used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013. [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has two backdoor modules called RC2FM and RC2CL that are used to perform post-exploitation activities. It has been discovered on compromised victims in the Ukraine and Russia. [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) infrastructure has been used to download and execute [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) against a small number of victims.(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2018)(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RedLeaves
Software description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) is a malware family used by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045). The code overlaps with [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) and may be based upon the open source tool Trochilus. (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017) (Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RDAT
Software description: [RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) is a backdoor used by the suspected Iranian threat group [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). [RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) was originally identified in 2017 and targeted companies in the telecommunications sector.(Citation: Unit42 RDAT July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zeus Panda
Software description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) is a Trojan designed to steal banking information and other sensitive credentials for exfiltration. [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330)’s original source code was leaked in 2011, allowing threat actors to use its source code as a basis for new malware variants. It is mainly used to target Windows operating systems ranging from Windows XP through Windows 10.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ZxShell
Software description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) is a remote administration tool and backdoor that can be downloaded from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites. It has been used since at least 2004.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POORAIM
Software description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) is a backdoor

entities.name: ZEBROCY
entities.description: Zebrocy is a Trojan that has been used by APT28 since at least November 2015, available in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, AutoIt, C#, VB.NET, and Golang.

entities.name: TAJMAHAL
entities.description: TajMahal is a multifunctional spying framework in use since at least 2014, comprised of two packages named Tokyo and Yokohama, capable of deploying up to 80 plugins.

entities.name: COBALT STRIKE
entities.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial remote access tool designed for adversary simulation, covering a full range of ATT&CK tactics within a single integrated system.

entities.name: SHARPSTAGE
entities.description: SharpStage is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.

entities.name: INVISIMOLE
entities.description: InvisiMole is a modular spyware program used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013, featuring two backdoor modules for post-exploitation activities.

entities.name: REDLEAVES
entities.description: RedLeaves is a malware family used by menuPass, with code overlapping with PlugX and possibly based on the open-source tool Trochilus.

entities.name: RDAT
entities.description: RDAT is a backdoor used by the suspected Iranian threat group OilRig, originally identified in 2017 and targeting telecommunications companies.

entities.name: ZEUS PANDA
entities.description: Zeus Panda is a Trojan designed to steal banking information and sensitive credentials, with its original source code leaked in 2011.

entities.name: ZXSHELL
entities.description: ZxShell is a remote administration tool and backdoor available from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites, in use since at least 2004.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a suspected Iranian cyber threat group known for its attacks on telecommunications and energy sectors, utilizing malware such as RDAT.

entities.name: GAMAREDON GROUP
entities.description: Gamaredon Group is a cyber threat actor known for its espionage activities, particularly targeting Ukrainian entities and using malware like InvisiMole.

entities.name: MENU PASS
entities.description: menuPass is a cyber espionage group that has been linked to various malware families, including RedLeaves.

entities.name: CISA
entities.description: CISA (Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency) is a U.S. government agency responsible for protecting the nation's critical infrastructure from cyber threats.

entities.name: KASPERSKY
entities.description: Kaspersky is a global cybersecurity company known for its antivirus products and research on cyber threats, including malware like TajMahal.

entities.name: PALO ALTO
entities.description: Palo Alto Networks is a cybersecurity company that provides advanced firewalls and cloud-based security solutions, involved in research on various malware.

entities.name: FIRE EYE
entities.description: FireEye is a cybersecurity company that provides threat intelligence and security solutions, known for its research on advanced persistent threats and malware.

itre.org/software/S0412) is a remote administration tool and backdoor that can be downloaded from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites. It has been used since at least 2004.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POORAIM
Software description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) is a backdoor used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) in campaigns since at least 2014. (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RCSession
Software description: [RCSession](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0662) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been in use since at least 2018 by [Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) and by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) (Type II Backdoor).(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE PRESIDENT December 2019)(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: UPPERCUT
Software description: [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) is a backdoor that has been used by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045). (Citation: FireEye APT10 Sept 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LitePower
Software description: [LitePower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0680) is a downloader and second stage malware that has been used by [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) since at least 2021.(Citation: Kaspersky WIRTE November 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BadPatch
Software description: [BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) is a Windows Trojan that was used in a Gaza Hackers-linked campaign.(Citation: Unit 42 BadPatch Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Aria-body
Software description: [Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) is a custom backdoor that has been used by [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) since approximately 2017.(Citation: CheckPoint Naikon May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Rover
Software description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) is malware suspected of being used for espionage purposes. It was used in 2015 in a targeted email sent to an Indian Ambassador to Afghanistan. (Citation: Palo Alto Rover)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Lizar
Software description: [Lizar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0681) is a modular remote access tool written using the .NET Framework that shares structural similarities to [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030). It has likely been used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) since at least February 2021.(Citation: BiZone Lizar May 2021)(Citation: Threatpost Lizar May 2021)(Citation: Gemini FIN7 Oct 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Peppy
Software description: [Peppy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0643) is a Python-based remote access Trojan, active since at least 2012, with similarities to [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115).(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Daserf
Software description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) is a backdoor that has been used to spy on and steal from Japanese, South Korean, Russian, Singaporean, and Chinese victims. Researchers have identified versions written in both Visual C and Delphi. (Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017) (Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TinyZBot
Software description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) is a bot written in C# that was developed by [Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Crimson
Software description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) is a remote access Trojan that has been used by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2016.(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky Transparent Tribe August 2020)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
has been used by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2016.(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky Transparent Tribe August 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CHOPSTICK
Software description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) is a malware family of modular backdoors used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It has been used since at least 2012 and is usually dropped on victims as second-stage malware, though it has been used as first-stage malware in several cases. It has both Windows and Linux variants. (Citation: FireEye APT28) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017) (Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018) It is tracked separately from the [X-Agent for Android](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0314).
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: ZLib
Software description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) is a full-featured backdoor that was used as a second-stage implant during [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016) since at least 2014. [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) is malware and should not be confused with the legitimate compression library from which its name is derived.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CosmicDuke
Software description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Attor
Software description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been seen in use since 2013. [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a loadable plugin architecture to customize functionality for specific targets.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: metaMain
Software description: [metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) is a backdoor used by [Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013) to maintain long-term access to compromised machines; it has also been used to decrypt [Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) into memory.(Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Sept 2022)(Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Technical Appendix Sept 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SVCReady
Software description: [SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) is a loader that has been used since at least April 2022 in malicious spam campaigns. Security researchers have noted overlaps between [TA551](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0127) activity and [SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) distribution, including similarities in file names, lure images, and identical grammatical errors.(Citation: HP SVCReady Jun 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Flame
Software description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) is a sophisticated toolkit that has been used to collect information since at least 2010, largely targeting Middle East countries. (Citation: Kaspersky Flame)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StrifeWater
Software description: [StrifeWater](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1034) is a remote-access tool that has been used by [Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) in the initial stages of their attacks since at least November 2021.(Citation: Cybereason StrifeWater Feb 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: VERMIN
Software description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is a remote access tool written in the Microsoft .NET framework. It is mostly composed of original code, but also has some open source code. (Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ursnif
Software description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) is a banking trojan and variant of the Gozi malware observed being spread through various automated exploit kits, [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001)s, and malicious links.(Citation: NJCCIC Ursnif Sept 2016)(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016) [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) is associated primarily with data theft, but variants also include components (backdoors, spyware, file injectors, etc.) capable of a wide variety of behaviors.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Woody RAT
Software description:  [Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.(Citation: MalwareBytes WoodyRAT Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LookBack
Software description: [LookBack](https://attack.mitre

entities.name: TRANSPARENT TRIBE
entities.description: Transparent Tribe is a cyber threat group that has been active since at least 2016, known for its use of malware and cyber espionage tactics.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a cyber espionage group associated with the Russian military intelligence, known for its sophisticated attacks and use of malware.

entities.name: CHOPSTICK
entities.description: CHOPSTICK is a malware family of modular backdoors used by APT28, typically deployed as second-stage malware since at least 2012.

entities.name: ZLIB
entities.description: ZLib is a backdoor malware used as a second-stage implant during Operation Dust Storm since at least 2014.

entities.name: COSMICDUKE
entities.description: CosmicDuke is malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, known for its espionage capabilities.

entities.name: ATTOR
entities.description: Attor is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been in use since 2013, featuring a loadable plugin architecture.

entities.name: METAMAIN
entities.description: metaMain is a backdoor used by Metador to maintain long-term access to compromised machines.

entities.name: SVCREADY
entities.description: SVCReady is a loader used in malicious spam campaigns since at least April 2022, associated with TA551 activity.

entities.name: FLAME
entities.description: Flame is a sophisticated toolkit used for information collection, primarily targeting Middle Eastern countries since at least 2010.

entities.name: STRIFEWATER
entities.description: StrifeWater is a remote-access tool used by Moses Staff in the initial stages of their attacks since at least November 2021.

entities.name: VERMIN
entities.description: VERMIN is a remote access tool written in .NET, combining original and open-source code.

entities.name: URSNIF
entities.description: Ursnif is a banking trojan variant of Gozi malware, primarily associated with data theft and spread through various exploit kits.

entities.name: WOODY RAT
entities.description: Woody RAT is a remote access trojan used against Russian organizations since at least August 2021.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group associated with the Russian government, known for its sophisticated malware and cyber operations.

entities.name: TA551
entities.description: TA551 is a cyber threat group known for its involvement in malicious spam campaigns and distribution of malware like SVCReady.

entities.name: MALWARE
entities.description: Malware is a general term for malicious software designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access to computer systems.

entities.name: MALICIOUS SPAM CAMPAIGNS
entities.description: Malicious spam campaigns are operations that use deceptive emails to distribute malware, such as SVCReady.

entities.name: CYBER ESPIONAGE
entities.description: Cyber espionage refers to the act of infiltrating a network to steal sensitive information, often associated with groups like APT28 and APT29.

entities.name: RUSSIAN ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Russian organizations are often targeted by various malware, including Woody RAT, which has been used against them since at least August 2021.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
Micro Ursnif Mar 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Woody RAT
Software description:  [Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.(Citation: MalwareBytes WoodyRAT Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LookBack
Software description: [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582) is a remote access trojan written in C++ that was used against at least three US utility companies in July 2019. The TALONITE activity group has been observed using [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582).(Citation: Proofpoint LookBack Malware Aug 2019)(Citation: Dragos TALONITE)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON
Software description: [ECCENTRICBANDWAGON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0593) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) used by North Korean cyber actors that was first identified in August 2020. It is a reconnaissance tool--with keylogging and screen capture functionality--used for information gathering on compromised systems.(Citation: CISA EB Aug 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mafalda
Software description: [Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) is a flexible interactive implant that has been used by [Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013). Security researchers assess the [Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) name may be inspired by an Argentinian cartoon character that has been popular as a means of political commentary since the 1960s. (Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Sept 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kivars
Software description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) is a modular remote access tool (RAT), derived from the Bifrost RAT, that was used by [BlackTech](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0098) in a 2010 campaign.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DOGCALL
Software description: [DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) is a backdoor used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that has been used to target South Korean government and military organizations in 2017. It is typically dropped using a Hangul Word Processor (HWP) exploit. (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: HyperBro
Software description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) is a custom in-memory backdoor used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027).(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)(Citation: Securelist LuckyMouse June 2018)(Citation: Hacker News LuckyMouse June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FunnyDream
Software description: [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) is a backdoor with multiple components that was used during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign since at least 2019, primarily for execution and exfiltration.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Chrommme
Software description: [Chrommme](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0667) is a backdoor tool written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework that was first reported in June 2021; security researchers noted infrastructure overlaps with [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) malware.(Citation: ESET Gelsemium June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FruitFly
Software description: FruitFly is designed to spy on mac users  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: NightClub
Software description: [NightClub](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1090) is a modular implant written in C++ that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2014.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FlawedAmmyy
Software description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first seen in early 2016. The code for [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) was based on leaked source code for a version of Ammyy Admin, a remote access software.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Matryoshka
Software description: [Matryoshka](https://attack.m

entities.description: Woody RAT is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.

entities.name: LOOKBACK
entities.description: LookBack is a remote access trojan written in C++ that was used against at least three US utility companies in July 2019.

entities.name: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON
entities.description: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON is a remote access Trojan (RAT) used by North Korean cyber actors, first identified in August 2020.

entities.name: MAFALDA
entities.description: Mafalda is a flexible interactive implant used by Metador, inspired by an Argentinian cartoon character.

entities.name: KIVARS
entities.description: Kivars is a modular remote access tool (RAT) used by BlackTech in a 2010 campaign.

entities.name: DOGCALL
entities.description: DOGCALL is a backdoor used by APT37 targeting South Korean government and military organizations since 2017.

entities.name: SYSUPDATE
entities.description: SysUpdate is a backdoor written in C++ used by Threat Group-3390 since at least 2020.

entities.name: HYPERBRO
entities.description: HyperBro is a custom in-memory backdoor used by Threat Group-3390.

entities.name: FUNNYDREAM
entities.description: FunnyDream is a backdoor used during the FunnyDream campaign since at least 2019 for execution and exfiltration.

entities.name: CHROMMME
entities.description: Chrommme is a backdoor tool written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework, first reported in June 2021.

entities.name: FRUITFLY
entities.description: FruitFly is designed to spy on macOS users.

entities.name: NIGHTCLUB
entities.description: NightClub is a modular implant written in C++ used by MoustachedBouncer since at least 2014.

entities.name: FLOODEDAMMYY
entities.description: FlawedAmmyy is a remote access tool (RAT) first seen in early 2016, based on leaked source code for Ammyy Admin.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a cyber threat group that has targeted South Korean government and military organizations using the DOGCALL backdoor.

entities.name: BLACKTECH
entities.description: BlackTech is a cyber threat group known for using the Kivars remote access tool in their campaigns.

entities.name: MUSTACHEDBOUNCER
entities.description: MoustachedBouncer is a cyber threat group that has utilized the NightClub implant in their operations.

entities.name: METADOR
entities.description: Metador is a cyber threat group associated with the use of the Mafalda interactive implant.

cyber threat group known for using the Kivars remote access tool in their campaigns.</data>      <data key="d2">d213731d875d5060fb7f64fccdbfc32d</data>    </node>    <node id="MUSTACHEDBOUNCER"> chunk:
1) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first seen in early 2016. The code for [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) was based on leaked source code for a version of Ammyy Admin, a remote access software.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Matryoshka
Software description: [Matryoshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) is a malware framework used by [CopyKittens](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0052) that consists of a dropper, loader, and RAT. It has multiple versions; v1 was seen in the wild from July 2016 until January 2017. v2 has fewer commands and other minor differences. (Citation: ClearSky Wilted Tulip July 2017) (Citation: CopyKittens Nov 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DustySky
Software description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) is multi-stage malware written in .NET that has been used by [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) since May 2015. (Citation: DustySky) (Citation: DustySky2)(Citation: Kaspersky MoleRATs April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bandook
Software description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) is a commercially available RAT, written in Delphi and C++, that has been available since at least 2007. It has been used against government, financial, energy, healthcare, education, IT, and legal organizations in the US, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia. [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has been used by [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070), as well as in a separate campaign referred to as "Operation Manul".(Citation: EFF Manul Aug 2016)(Citation: Lookout Dark Caracal Jan 2018)(Citation: CheckPoint Bandook Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Hydraq
Software description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) is a data-theft trojan first used by [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) in the 2009 Google intrusion known as Operation Aurora, though variations of this trojan have been used in more recent campaigns by other Chinese actors, possibly including [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025).(Citation: MicroFocus 9002 Aug 2016)(Citation: Symantec Elderwood Sept 2012)(Citation: Symantec Trojan.Hydraq Jan 2010)(Citation: ASERT Seven Pointed Dagger Aug 2015)(Citation: FireEye DeputyDog 9002 November 2013)(Citation: ProofPoint GoT 9002 Aug 2017)(Citation: FireEye Sunshop Campaign May 2013)(Citation: PaloAlto 3102 Sept 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RainyDay
Software description: [RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) is a backdoor tool that has been used by [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) since at least 2020.(Citation: Bitdefender Naikon April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kasidet
Software description: [Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) is a backdoor that has been dropped by using malicious VBA macros. (Citation: Zscaler Kasidet)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KONNI
Software description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) is a remote access tool that security researchers assess has been used by North Korean cyber actors since at least 2014. [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has significant code overlap with the [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) malware family, and has been linked to several suspected North Korean campaigns targeting political organizations in Russia, East Asia, Europe and the Middle East; there is some evidence potentially linking [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) to [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067).(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)(Citation: Malwarebytes Konni Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: gh0st RAT
Software description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) is a remote access tool (RAT). The source code is public and it has been used by multiple groups.(Citation: FireEye Hacking Team)(Citation: Arbor Musical Chairs Feb 2018)(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: Kazuar
Software description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework. (Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)
Platforms:

entities.description: DustySky is multi-stage malware written in .NET, used by Molerats since May 2015.

entities.name: BANDOOK
entities.description: Bandook is a commercially available RAT, used against various organizations globally since at least 2007.

entities.name: HYDRAQ
entities.description: Hydraq is a data-theft trojan first used by Elderwood in the 2009 Google intrusion known as Operation Aurora.

entities.name: RAINYDAY
entities.description: RainyDay is a backdoor tool used by Naikon since at least 2020.

entities.description: Kasidet is a backdoor dropped using malicious VBA macros.

entities.name: KONNI
entities.description: KONNI is a remote access tool used by North Korean cyber actors since at least 2014, linked to several campaigns.

entities.description: gh0st RAT is a remote access tool with public source code, used by multiple groups.

entities.description: Kazuar is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework.

entities.name: MOLERATS
entities.description: Molerats is a group that has utilized DustySky malware since May 2015 in cyber attacks.

entities.name: DARK CARACAL
entities.description: Dark Caracal is a group that has used Bandook malware in various cyber campaigns against multiple sectors.

entities.name: ELDERWOOD
entities.description: Elderwood is a group known for using the Hydrq data-theft trojan in significant cyber intrusions.
