chunk:
.(Citation: FireEye Hacking Team)(Citation: Arbor Musical Chairs Feb 2018)(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: Kazuar
Software description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework. (Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: EvilGrab
Software description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) is a malware family with common reconnaissance capabilities. It has been deployed by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) via malicious Microsoft Office documents as part of spearphishing campaigns. (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HALFBAKED
Software description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) is a malware family consisting of multiple components intended to establish persistence in victim networks. (Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)
Platforms: None

Software name: Metamorfo
Software description: [Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group that has been active since at least April 2018. The group focuses on targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.(Citation: Medium Metamorfo Apr 2020)(Citation: ESET Casbaneiro Oct 2019) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: yty
Software description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) is a modular, plugin-based malware framework. The components of the framework are written in a variety of programming languages. (Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Micropsia
Software description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) is a remote access tool written in Delphi.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SMOKEDHAM
Software description: [SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) is a Powershell-based .NET backdoor that was first reported in May 2021; it has been used by at least one ransomware-as-a-service affiliate.(Citation: FireEye Shining A Light on DARKSIDE May 2021)(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PlugX
Software description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) is a remote access tool (RAT) with modular plugins that has been used by multiple threat groups.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Fox Part 2)(Citation: New DragonOK)(Citation: Dell TG-3390)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KeyBoy
Software description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) is malware that has been used in targeted campaigns against members of the Tibetan Parliament in 2016.(Citation: CitizenLab KeyBoy Nov 2016)(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Socksbot
Software description: [Socksbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0273) is a backdoor that  abuses Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies. (Citation: TrendMicro Patchwork Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: XAgentOSX
Software description: [XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) is a trojan that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007)  on OS X and appears to be a port of their standard [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) or XAgent trojan. (Citation: XAgentOSX 2017)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: KEYMARBLE
Software description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) is a Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government. (Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ROKRAT
Software description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) is a cloud-based remote access tool (RAT) used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) to target victims in South Korea. [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used ROKRAT during several campaigns from 2016 through 2021.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: Talos Group123)(Citation: Volexity InkySquid RokRAT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Derusbi
Software description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is malware

entities.name: KAZUAR
entities.description: Kazuar is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework.

entities.name: EVILGRAB
entities.description: EvilGrab is a malware family with common reconnaissance capabilities, deployed via malicious Microsoft Office documents as part of spearphishing campaigns.

entities.name: HALFBAKED
entities.description: HALFBAKED is a malware family consisting of multiple components intended to establish persistence in victim networks.

entities.name: METAMORFO
entities.description: Metamorfo is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.

entities.name: YTY
entities.description: YTY is a modular, plugin-based malware framework with components written in various programming languages.

entities.name: MICROPSIA
entities.description: Micropsia is a remote access tool written in Delphi.

entities.name: SMOKEDHAM
entities.description: SMOKEDHAM is a Powershell-based .NET backdoor used by at least one ransomware-as-a-service affiliate.

entities.name: PLUGX
entities.description: PlugX is a remote access tool (RAT) with modular plugins used by multiple threat groups.

entities.name: KEYBOY
entities.description: KeyBoy is malware used in targeted campaigns against members of the Tibetan Parliament in 2016.

entities.name: SOCKSBOT
entities.description: Socksbot is a backdoor that abuses Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies.

entities.name: XAGENTOSX
entities.description: XAgentOSX is a trojan used by APT28 on OS X, appearing to be a port of their standard CHOPSTICK or XAgent trojan.

entities.name: KEYMARBLE
entities.description: KEYMARBLE is a Trojan reportedly used by the North Korean government.

entities.name: ROKRAT
entities.description: ROKRAT is a cloud-based remote access tool (RAT) used by APT37 to target victims in South Korea.

entities.name: REVENGE RAT
entities.description: Revenge RAT is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).

entities.name: ARBOR MUSICAL CHAIRS
entities.description: Arbor Musical Chairs is an event that took place in February 2018, likely related to cybersecurity discussions or activities.

entities.name: NCCGROUP
entities.description: NCC Group is a global expert in cyber security and risk mitigation, providing services to help organizations protect their data.

entities.name: UNIT 42
entities.description: Unit 42 is a threat intelligence team at Palo Alto Networks that analyzes and reports on cybersecurity threats and malware.

entities.name: PWC
entities.description: PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) is a multinational professional services network providing audit, assurance, consulting, and tax services.

entities.name: ESET
entities.description: ESET is a global cybersecurity company that provides antivirus and anti-malware solutions.

entities.name: TALOS
entities.description: Talos is a threat intelligence organization within Cisco that provides security research and analysis.

entities.name: TRENDMICRO
entities.description: Trend Micro is a global cybersecurity company that provides security software and solutions for businesses and consumers.

entities.name: DELL
entities.description: Dell is a multinational computer technology company that develops, sells, and supports computers and related products and services.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a Russian cyber espionage group known for its sophisticated cyber attacks against various targets.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a North Korean cyber espionage group that conducts cyber operations against South Korean targets and other nations.

entities.name: CITIZENLAB
entities.description: Citizen Lab is an interdisciplinary laboratory based at the Munk School of Global Affairs at the University of Toronto, focusing on the intersection of technology and human rights.

entities.name: FIREEYE FIN7
entities.description: FireEye FIN7 is a cybercriminal group known for its sophisticated attacks and use of malware in financial theft.

entities.description: CloudBreach is a cybersecurity firm that specializes in cloud security and data protection.

key="d5">9e20435861c2ef9933a00fbd47b0e501</data>    </edge>    <edge source="UNIT 42" target="FIREEYE HACKING TEAM">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">Unit 42 is part of FireEye and include information on APT28's cyber activities.</data>      <data key="d5">9e20435861c2ef9933a00fbd47b0e501</data>    </edge>    <edge source="TALOS" target="APT37">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">APT37 is a target of Talos's threat intelligence research and reporting.</data>      <data key="d5">9e20435861c2ef9933a00fbd47b0e501</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Derusbi
Software description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is malware used by multiple Chinese APT groups.(Citation: Novetta-Axiom)(Citation: ThreatConnect Anthem) Both Windows and Linux variants have been observed.(Citation: Fidelis Turbo)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: NETWIRE
Software description: [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: McAfee Netwire Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Proton
Software description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) is a macOS backdoor focusing on data theft and credential access  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: AppleSeed
Software description: [AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) is a backdoor that has been used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) to target South Korean government, academic, and commercial  targets since at least 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Kimsuky June 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: Remexi
Software description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) is a Windows-based Trojan that was developed in the C programming language.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SHUTTERSPEED
Software description: [SHUTTERSPEED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0217) is a backdoor used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067). (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: None

Software name: PoetRAT
Software description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that was first identified in April 2020. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has been used in multiple campaigns against the private and public sectors in Azerbaijan, including ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector. The STIBNITE activity group has been observed using the malware. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) derived its name from references in the code to poet William Shakespeare. (Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)(Citation: Talos PoetRAT October 2020)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cadelspy
Software description: [Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) is a backdoor that has been used by [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087).(Citation: Symantec Chafer Dec 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: T9000
Software description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) is a backdoor that is a newer variant of the T5000 malware family, also known as Plat1. Its primary function is to gather information about the victim. It has been used in multiple targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations. (Citation: FireEye admin@338 March 2014) (Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CharmPower
Software description: [CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) is a PowerShell-based, modular backdoor that has been used by [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) since at least 2022.(Citation: Check Point APT35 CharmPower January 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Carberp
Software description: [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) is a credential and information stealing malware that has been active since at least 2009. [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s source code was leaked online in 2013, and subsequently used as the foundation for the [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) backdoor.(Citation: Trend Micro Carberp February 2014)(Citation: KasperskyCarbanak)(Citation: RSA Carbanak November 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BLUELIGHT
Software description: [BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) is a remote access Trojan used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that was first observed in early 2021.(Citation: Volexity InkySquid BLUELIGHT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MacSpy
Software description: [MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282) is a malware-as-a-service offered

entities.name: MAGIC HOUND
entities.description: Magic Hound is a cyber threat group that has employed CharmPower in its operations since at least 2022.

chunk:
BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) is a remote access Trojan used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that was first observed in early 2021.(Citation: Volexity InkySquid BLUELIGHT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MacSpy
Software description: [MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282) is a malware-as-a-service offered on the darkweb  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Software description: [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) is a remote access Trojan written in C++ that has been used by an unidentified "sophisticated cyber actor" since at least January 2017.(Citation: CISA MAR SLOTHFULMEDIA October 2020)(Citation: Costin Raiu IAmTheKing October 2020) It has been used to target government organizations, defense contractors, universities, and energy companies in Russia, India, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Malaysia, Ukraine, and Eastern Europe.(Citation: USCYBERCOM SLOTHFULMEDIA October 2020)(Citation: Kaspersky IAmTheKing October 2020)  

In October 2020, Kaspersky Labs assessed [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) is part of an activity cluster it refers to as "IAmTheKing".(Citation: Kaspersky IAmTheKing October 2020) ESET also noted code similarity between [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) and droppers used by a group it refers to as "PowerPool".(Citation: ESET PowerPool Code October 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RogueRobin
Software description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) is a payload used by [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) that has been developed in PowerShell and C#. (Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Chaes
Software description: [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) is a multistage information stealer written in several programming languages that collects login credentials, credit card numbers, and other financial information. [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) was first observed in 2020, and appears to primarily target victims in Brazil as well as other e-commerce customers in Latin America.(Citation: Cybereason Chaes Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWERSTATS
Software description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069). (Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) have been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform, similar to an online subscription model.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016) (Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: POWRUNER
Software description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server. (Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Azorult
Software description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) is a commercial Trojan that is used to steal information from compromised hosts. [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) has been observed in the wild as early as 2016.
In July 2018, [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) was seen used in a spearphishing campaign against targets in North America. [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) has been seen used for cryptocurrency theft. (Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HotCroissant
Software description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed by U.S. government entities to malicious North Korean government cyber activity, tracked collectively as HIDDEN COBRA.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020) [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) shares numerous code similarities with [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433).(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StoneDrill
Software description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against both Middle Eastern and European targets in association with [APT33](https://attack.mitre

entities.name: BLUELIGHT
entities.description: BLUELIGHT is a remote access Trojan used by APT37, first observed in early 2021, and operates on Windows platforms.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a cyber threat group associated with the use of the BLUELIGHT Trojan for malicious activities.

entities.name: MACSPY
entities.description: MacSpy is a malware-as-a-service offered on the dark web, targeting macOS platforms.

entities.name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
entities.description: SLOTHFULMEDIA is a remote access Trojan used by an unidentified sophisticated cyber actor since at least January 2017, targeting various organizations across multiple countries.

entities.name: DARKHYDRUS
entities.description: DarkHydrus is a cyber threat group that uses RogueRobin as a payload developed in PowerShell and C#.

entities.name: CHAES
entities.description: Chaes is a multistage information stealer that collects sensitive information, primarily targeting victims in Brazil and Latin America since 2020.

entities.name: MUDDYWATER
entities.description: MuddyWater is a cyber threat group that utilizes POWERSTATS as a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor.

entities.name: JRAT
entities.description: jRAT is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor available for purchase since 2012, distributed via a software-as-a-service platform.

entities.name: POWRUNER
entities.description: POWRUNER is a PowerShell script that facilitates command and control communication with a C2 server.

entities.name: AZORULT
entities.description: Azorult is a commercial Trojan used for information theft, observed in campaigns targeting North America and cryptocurrency theft since 2016.

entities.name: HOTCROISSANT
entities.description: HotCroissant is a remote access Trojan attributed to North Korean cyber activity, sharing code similarities with Rifdoor.

entities.name: STONEDRILL
entities.description: StoneDrill is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against Middle Eastern and European targets, associated with APT33.

entities.name: APT34
entities.description: APT34 is a cyber threat group that utilizes POWRUNER as a PowerShell script for command and control operations.

entities.name: ESET
entities.description: ESET is a cybersecurity company that noted code similarity between SLOTHFULMEDIA and droppers used by a group it refers to as PowerPool.

entities.name: KASPERSKY
entities.description: Kaspersky is a cybersecurity company that assessed SLOTHFULMEDIA as part of an activity cluster it refers to as "IAmTheKing."

entities.name: US-CERT
entities.description: US-CERT is a government entity that attributed HotCroissant to malicious North Korean government cyber activity.

backdoor, indicating a direct relationship</data>      <data key="d5">d97209a3adfcd019d69b5f4f971f16d1</data>    </edge>    <edge source="MUDDYWATER" target="APT34">      <data key="d3">1.0</data> chunk:
attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) shares numerous code similarities with [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433).(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StoneDrill
Software description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against both Middle Eastern and European targets in association with [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064).(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Catchamas
Software description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) is a Windows Trojan that steals information from compromised systems. (Citation: Symantec Catchamas April 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NKAbuse
Software description: [NKAbuse](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1107) is a Go-based, multi-platform malware abusing NKN (New Kind of Network) technology for data exchange between peers, functioning as a potent implant, and equipped with both flooder and backdoor capabilities.(Citation: NKAbuse BC)(Citation: NKAbuse SL)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Cardinal RAT
Software description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is a potentially low volume remote access trojan (RAT) observed since December 2015. [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is notable for its unique utilization of uncompiled C# source code and the Microsoft Windows built-in csc.exe compiler.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Octopus
Software description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) is a Windows Trojan written in the Delphi programming language that has been used by [Nomadic Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0133) to target government organizations in Central Asia since at least 2014.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)(Citation: Security Affairs DustSquad Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Nomadic Octopus 2018) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RTM
Software description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) is custom malware written in Delphi. It is used by the group of the same name ([RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048)). Newer versions of the malware have been reported publicly as Redaman.(Citation: ESET RTM Feb 2017)(Citation: Unit42 Redaman January 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuietSieve
Software description: [QuietSieve](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0686) is an information stealer that has been used by [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) since at least 2021.(Citation: Microsoft Actinium February 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Machete
Software description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) is a cyber espionage toolset used by [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0095). It is a Python-based backdoor targeting Windows machines that was first observed in 2010.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)(Citation: 360 Machete Sep 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Janicab
Software description: [Janicab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0163) is an OS X trojan that relied on a valid developer ID and oblivious users to install it. (Citation: Janicab)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: MarkiRAT
Software description: [MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) compiled with Visual Studio that has been used by [Ferocious Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0137) since at least 2015.(Citation: Kaspersky Ferocious Kitten Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 1 software using the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle. Their names are as follows:
* Dok

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Dok
Software description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that is able to collect user credentials and install a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic (i.e. [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557)).(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: hexed osx.dok analysis 2019)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)
Platforms: macOS

entities.name: DOK
entities.description: Dok is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that collects user credentials and installs a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic, operating on macOS.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. for Macintosh computers, on which the Dok software operates.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 1 software using the attack technique called Startup Items. Their names are as follows:
* jRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) have been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform, similar to an online subscription model.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016) (Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

entities.name: JRAT
entities.description: jRAT is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor software that was originally available for purchase in 2012 and has been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform.

entities.name: CROSS-PLATFORM
entities.description: Cross-platform indicates that jRAT operates on multiple operating systems, including Linux, Windows, macOS, and Android.

entities.name: JAVA
entities.description: Java is a programming language and computing platform that jRAT is based on, allowing it to function across different systems.

entities.name: SOFTWARE-AS-A-SERVICE
entities.description: Software-as-a-service is a distribution model in which software is hosted in the cloud and accessed via the internet, which applies to how jRAT has been distributed.

There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Windows Management Instrumentation. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute malicious commands and payloads. WMI is designed for programmers and is the infrastructure for management data and operations on Windows systems.(Citation: WMI 1-3) WMI is an administration feature that provides a uniform environment to access Windows system components.

The WMI service enables both local and remote access, though the latter is facilitated by [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Windows Remote Management](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/006).(Citation: WMI 1-3) Remote WMI over DCOM operates using port 135, whereas WMI over WinRM operates over port 5985 when using HTTP and 5986 for HTTPS.(Citation: WMI 1-3) (Citation: Mandiant WMI)

An adversary can use WMI to interact with local and remote systems and use it as a means to execute various behaviors, such as gathering information for [Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0007) as well as [Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002) of commands and payloads.(Citation: Mandiant WMI) For example, `wmic.exe` can be abused by an adversary to delete shadow copies with the command `wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete` (i.e., [Inhibit System Recovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1490)).(Citation: WMI 6)

**Note:** `wmic.exe` is deprecated as of January of 2024, with the WMIC feature being “disabled by default” on Windows 11+. WMIC will be removed from subsequent Windows releases and replaced by [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) as the primary WMI interface.(Citation: WMI 7,8) In addition to PowerShell and tools like `wbemtool.exe`, COM APIs can also be used to programmatically interact with WMI via C++, .NET, VBScript, etc.(Citation: WMI 7,8)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: WINDOWS MANAGEMENT INSTRUMENTATION
entities.description: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) is an attack technique that allows adversaries to execute malicious commands and payloads on Windows systems, providing a uniform environment to access system components.

entities.name: WMIC.EXE
entities.description: WMIC.exe is a command-line utility that can be abused by adversaries to execute commands such as deleting shadow copies, but it is deprecated as of January 2024 and will be removed from future Windows releases.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is the operating system platform that WMI targets for executing commands and managing system components.

entities.name: REMOTE SERVICES
entities.description: Remote Services are services that facilitate remote access to Windows Management Instrumentation, allowing adversaries to interact with systems from a distance.

entities.name: DISTRIBUTED COMPONENT OBJECT MODEL
entities.description: Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) is a Microsoft technology that allows software components to communicate directly over a network, often used in conjunction with WMI for remote access.

entities.name: WINDOWS REMOTE MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Windows Remote Management (WinRM) is a Microsoft implementation of the WS-Management protocol that allows for remote management of Windows machines, also utilized by WMI.

entities.name: SHADOW COPIES
entities.description: Shadow copies are backup copies of files or volumes that can be deleted using commands executed through WMI, specifically with the `wmic.exe` command.

entities.name: POWER SHELL
entities.description: PowerShell is a task automation and configuration management framework from Microsoft, which will replace WMIC as the primary WMI interface in future Windows releases.

entities.name: COM APIS
entities.description: COM APIs are interfaces that allow programmatic interaction with Windows Management Instrumentation, enabling developers to manage system components using various programming languages.

* Impacket
* Empire
* PoshC2
* Pupy
* Responder

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Responder
Software description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS and MDNS poisoning, with built-in HTTP/SMB/MSSQL/FTP/LDAP rogue authentication server supporting NTLMv1/NTLMv2/LMv2, Extended Security NTLMSSP and Basic HTTP authentication. (Citation: GitHub Responder)
Platforms: None

entities.name: POSHC2

entities.name: PUPY
entities.description: Pupy is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation tool written in Python, capable of being generated as various payloads for multiple operating systems.

entities.name: RESPONDER
entities.description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS, and MDNS poisoning, featuring built-in rogue authentication servers for various protocols.

entities.name: NBT-NS
entities.description: NBT-NS (NetBIOS Name Service) is a network protocol used for name resolution in Windows networks, which can also be targeted in poisoning attacks.

entities.name: SMB RELAY
entities.description: SMB Relay is an attack technique that exploits the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol to intercept and relay authentication requests, often used in conjunction with other attacks.)<|COMPLETE|>

Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PolyglotDuke
Software description: [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) is a downloader that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2013. [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) has been used to drop [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051).(Citation: ESET Dukes October 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TYPEFRAME
Software description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) is a remote access tool that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). (Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ShadowPad
Software description: [ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) is a modular backdoor that was first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017. The malware was originally thought to be exclusively used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096), but has since been observed to be used by various Chinese threat activity groups. (Citation: Recorded Future RedEcho Feb 2021)(Citation: Securelist ShadowPad Aug 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky ShadowPad Aug 2017) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gelsemium
Software description: [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) is a modular malware comprised of a dropper (Gelsemine), a loader (Gelsenicine), and main (Gelsevirine) plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework. [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has been used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014.(Citation: ESET Gelsemium June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Uroburos
Software description: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos

key="d1">DarkWatchman is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="POLYGLOTDUKE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">PolyglotDuke is a downloader that has been used by APT29 since at least 2013 and has been used to drop MiniDuke.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="QAKBOT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">QakBot is a modular banking trojan used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007, evolving from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="TYPEFRAME">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">TYPEFRAME is a remote access tool that has been used by the Lazarus Group.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="COMRAT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">ComRAT is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of Agent.btz and used by Turla, first identified in 2007.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="SHADOWPAD">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">ShadowPad is a modular backdoor first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017, used by various Chinese threat activity groups.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="GELSEMIUM">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Gelsemium is a modular malware used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014, comprised of a dropper, a loader, and main plug-ins.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="UROBUROS">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Uroburos is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool used by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="PILLOWMINT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Pillowmint is a malware tool that has been utilized in cyber attacks, particularly in the context of espionage and data theft.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="TINY TURLA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">TinyTurla is a malware variant associated with the Turla group, known for its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="CHOPSTICK">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">CHOPSTICK is a malware tool that has been linked to various cyber operations, often used for data exfiltration.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="QUADAGENT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">QUADAGENT is a malware tool that has been involved in cyber attacks, particularly targeting sensitive information.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="REGDUKE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">REGDUKE is a malware tool that has been used in cyber key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">THREATNEEDLE is a malware tool that has been utilized in various cyber attacks, particularly in the context of financial theft.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="VALAK">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">VALAK is a malware tool known for its capabilities in data key="d1">VOLGMER is a malware tool associated with cyber espionage and data theft operations.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="CHAES">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">CHAES is a malware tool that has been used in various cyber operations, often linked to financial crime.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="RCSESSION">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">RCSession is a remote access tool that has been key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Sibot is a malware tool that has been involved in cyber operations, often associated with espionage and data theft.</data>      <data     <data key="d1">REvil is a ransomware group known for its sophisticated attacks and data exfiltration tactics.</data>      <data key="d2">1f70773d2329bf268c65a449b4ef5396</data>    </node>    <node id="MOSQUITO">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Mosquito is a malware tool that has been utilized in cyber operations, often linked to financial theft and key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both Gelsemium and Uroburos are sophisticated malware tools used for cyber espionage, suggesting a relationship in their operational context.</data>      <data chunk:
set to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: Exaramel for Windows
Software description: [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343) is a backdoor used for targeting Windows systems. The Linux version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Grandoreiro
Software description: [Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) is a banking trojan written in Delphi that was first observed in 2016 and uses a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) business model. [Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) has confirmed victims in Brazil, Mexico, Portugal, and Spain.(Citation: Securelist Brazilian Banking Malware July 2020)(Citation: ESET Grandoreiro April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NETWIRE
Software description: [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: McAfee Netwire Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Pillowmint
Software description: [Pillowmint](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0517) is a point-of-sale malware used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) designed to capture credit card information.(Citation: Trustwave Pillowmint June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TinyTurla
Software description: [TinyTurla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0668) is a backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) against targets in the US, Germany, and Afghanistan since at least 2020.(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CHOPSTICK
Software description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) is a malware family of modular backdoors used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It has been used since at least 2012 and is usually dropped on victims as second-stage malware, though it has been used as first-stage malware in several cases. It has both Windows and Linux variants. (Citation: FireEye APT28) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017) (Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018) It is tracked separately from the [X-Agent for Android](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0314).
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: QUADAGENT
Software description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). (Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RegDuke
Software description: [RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511) is a first stage implant written in .NET and used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2017. [RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511) has been used to control a compromised machine when control of other implants on the machine was lost.(Citation: ESET Dukes October 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ThreatNeedle
Software description: [ThreatNeedle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0665) is a backdoor that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) since at least 2019 to target cryptocurrency, defense, and mobile gaming organizations.  It is considered to be an advanced cluster of [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032)'s Manuscrypt (a.k.a. NukeSped) malware family.(Citation: Kaspersky Threat

entities.name: UROBUROS
entities.description: Uroburos is a sophisticated malware that has undergone constant upgrades since its initial development in 2003, designed to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide and capable of operating on various platforms including Windows, Linux, and macOS.

entities.name: SYSUPDATE
entities.description: SysUpdate is a backdoor software written in C++ used by Threat Group-3390 since at least 2020, compatible with Windows and Linux platforms.

entities.name: EXARAMEL FOR WINDOWS
entities.description: Exaramel for Windows is a backdoor targeting Windows systems, with a separate Linux version tracked as Exaramel for Linux.

entities.name: GRANDOREIRO
entities.description: Grandoreiro is a banking trojan written in Delphi, first observed in 2016, utilizing a Malware-as-a-Service business model and confirmed to have victims in Brazil, Mexico, Portugal, and Spain.

entities.name: NETWIRE
entities.description: NETWIRE is a publicly available multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.

entities.name: PILLOWMINT
entities.description: Pillowmint is a point-of-sale malware used by FIN7, designed specifically to capture credit card information.

entities.name: TINY TURLA
entities.description: TinyTurla is a backdoor used by Turla against targets in the US, Germany, and Afghanistan since at least 2020.

entities.name: CHOPSTICK
entities.description: CHOPSTICK is a modular backdoor malware family used by APT28 since at least 2012, often dropped as second-stage malware.

entities.name: QUADAGENT
entities.description: QUADAGENT is a PowerShell backdoor used by OilRig, designed for stealthy operations.

entities.name: REGDUKE
entities.description: RegDuke is a first-stage implant written in .NET, used by APT29 since at least 2017 to control compromised machines.

entities.name: THREATNEEDLE
entities.description: ThreatNeedle is a backdoor used by the Lazarus Group since at least 2019, targeting cryptocurrency, defense, and mobile gaming organizations.

entities.name: TURNA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber threat group that has utilized the TinyTurla backdoor against various targets since at least 2020.

entities.name: FIN7
entities.description: FIN7 is a cybercriminal group known for using the Pillowmint malware to capture credit card information.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a well-known advanced persistent threat group that has used the CHOPSTICK malware family since at least 2012.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a cyber threat group that employs the QUADAGENT PowerShell backdoor for its operations.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber threat group that has utilized the RegDuke implant since at least 2017.

It is considered to be an advanced cluster of [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032)'s Manuscrypt (a.k.a. NukeSped) malware family.(Citation: Kaspersky ThreatNeedle Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Volgmer
Software description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) is a backdoor Trojan designed to provide covert access to a compromised system. It has been used since at least 2013 to target the government, financial, automotive, and media industries. Its primary delivery mechanism is suspected to be spearphishing. (Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Chaes
Software description: [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) is a multistage information stealer written in several programming languages that collects login credentials, credit card numbers, and other financial information. [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) was first observed in 2020, and appears to primarily target victims in Brazil as well as other e-commerce customers in Latin America.(Citation: Cybereason Chaes Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RCSession
Software description: [RCSession](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0662) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been in use since at least 2018 by [Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) and by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) (Type II Backdoor).(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE PRESIDENT December 2019)(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sibot
Software description: [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) is dual-purpose malware written in VBScript designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system as well as download and execute additional payloads. Microsoft discovered three [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) variants in early 2021 during its investigation of [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) and the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024).(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PipeMon
Software description: [PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) is a multi-stage modular backdoor used by [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044).(Citation: ESET PipeMon May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: REvil
Software description: [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) is a ransomware family that has been linked to the [GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) group and operated as ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) since at least April 2019. [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496), which as been used against organizations in the manufacturing, transportation, and electric sectors, is highly configurable and shares code similarities with the GandCrab RaaS.(Citation: Secureworks REvil September 2019)(Citation: Intel 471 REvil March 2020)(Citation: Group IB Ransomware May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mosquito
Software description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) is a Win32 backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) is made up of three parts: the installer, the launcher, and the backdoor. The main backdoor is called CommanderDLL and is launched by the loader program. (Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: LAZARUS GROUP
entities.description: Lazarus Group is a cybercriminal organization known for its advanced persistent threat (APT) activities, particularly targeting cryptocurrency, defense, and mobile gaming sectors since at least 2019.

entities.name: VALAK
entities.description: Valak is a multi-stage modular malware that functions as an information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.

entities.name: VOLGMER
entities.description: Volgmer is a backdoor Trojan used since at least 2013 to target government, financial, automotive, and media industries, primarily delivered through spearphishing.

entities.name: CHAES
entities.description: Chaes is a multistage information stealer that collects sensitive financial information, first observed in 2020, primarily targeting victims in Brazil and Latin America.

entities.name: RCSSESSION
entities.description: RCSession is a backdoor written in C++ used since at least 2018 by Mustang Panda and Threat Group-3390.

entities.name: SIBOT
entities.description: Sibot is dual-purpose malware designed for persistence on compromised systems and downloading additional payloads, discovered during investigations of APT29 and the SolarWinds Compromise.

entities.name: PIPEMON
entities.description: PipeMon is a multi-stage modular backdoor used by Winnti Group.

entities.name: REVIL
entities.description: REvil is a ransomware family linked to the GOLD SOUTHFIELD group, operating as ransomware-as-a-service since at least April 2019, targeting various sectors including manufacturing and transportation.

entities.name: MOSQUITO
entities.description: Mosquito is a Win32 backdoor used by Turla, consisting of an installer, launcher, and backdoor component called CommanderDLL.

entities.name: THREAT GROUP-3390
entities.description: Threat Group-3390 is a cybercriminal organization that has been associated with the use of the RCSession backdoor in cyber operations.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, is a Russian cyber espionage group that has been linked to various cyber attacks, including the SolarWinds Compromise.

entities.name: SOLARWINDS COMPROMISE
entities.description: The SolarWinds Compromise refers to a significant cyber attack that involved the infiltration of the SolarWinds software supply chain, affecting numerous organizations globally.

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: CSPY Downloader
Software description: [CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) is a tool designed to evade analysis and download additional payloads used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094).(Citation: Cybereason Kimsuky November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: IronNetInjector
Software description: [IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) is a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolchain that utilizes scripts from the open-source IronPython implementation of Python with a .NET injector to drop one or more payloads including [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126).(Citation: Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021 )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MCMD
Software description: [MCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0500) is a remote access tool that provides remote command shell capability used by [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074).(Citation: Secureworks MCMD July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: schtasks
Software description: [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) is used to schedule execution of programs or scripts on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time. (Citation: TechNet Schtasks)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity

chunk:
TechNet Schtasks)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AsyncRAT
Software description: [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087) is an open-source remote access tool originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository that has been used in malicious campaigns.(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Cisco Operation Layover September 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GoldMax
Software description: [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go with Windows and Linux variants that are nearly identical in functionality. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) was discovered in early 2021 during the investigation into the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), and has likely been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least mid-2019. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) uses multiple defense evasion techniques, including avoiding virtualization execution and masking malicious traffic.(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: FireEye SUNSHUTTLE Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike StellarParticle January 2022)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: JSS Loader
Software description: [JSS Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0648) is Remote Access Trojan (RAT) with .NET and C++ variants that has been used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) since at least 2020.(Citation: eSentire FIN7 July 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike Carbon Spider August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BabyShark
Software description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) is a Microsoft Visual Basic (VB) script-based malware family that is believed to be associated with several North Korean campaigns. (Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DanBot
Software description: [DanBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1014) is a first-stage remote access Trojan written in C# that has been used by [HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) since at least 2018.(Citation: SecureWorks August 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Helminth
Software description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) is a backdoor that has at least two variants - one written in VBScript and PowerShell that is delivered via a macros in Excel spreadsheets, and one that is a standalone Windows executable. (Citation: Palo Alto OilRig May 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Milan
Software description: [Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015) is a backdoor implant based on [DanBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1014) that was written in Visual C++ and .NET. [Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015) has been used by [HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) since at least June 2020.(Citation: ClearSky Siamesekitten August 2021)(Citation: Kaspersky Lyceum October 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HermeticWiper
Software description: [HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) is a data wiper that has been used since at least early 2022, primarily against Ukraine with additional activity observed in Latvia and Lithuania. Some sectors targeted include government, financial, defense, aviation, and IT services.(Citation: SentinelOne Hermetic Wiper February 2022)(Citation: Symantec Ukraine Wipers February 2022)(Citation: Crowdstrike DriveSlayer February 2022)(Citation: ESET Hermetic Wiper February 2022)(Citation: Qualys Hermetic Wiper March 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TrickBot
Software description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) is a Trojan spyware program written in C++ that first emerged in September 2016 as a possible successor to [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024). [TrickBot](https://attack

entities.name: QUASARRAT
entities.description: QuasarRAT is an open-source remote access tool developed in C# and publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014.

entities.name: KOADIC
entities.description: Koadic is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool available on GitHub, known for its payload staging and implant creation capabilities.

entities.name: ASYNCRAT
entities.description: AsyncRAT is an open-source remote access tool that has been used in malicious campaigns, originally available through the NYANxCAT GitHub repository.

entities.name: GOLDMAX
entities.description: GoldMax is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go, discovered during the investigation into the SolarWinds Compromise, and used by APT29 since at least mid-2019.

entities.name: JSS LOADER
entities.description: JSS Loader is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) with .NET and C++ variants, used by FIN7 since at least 2020.

entities.name: BABYSHARK
entities.description: BabyShark is a Microsoft Visual Basic script-based malware family believed to be associated with several North Korean campaigns.

entities.name: DANBOT
entities.description: DanBot is a first-stage remote access Trojan written in C# that has been used by HEXANE since at least 2018.

entities.name: HELMINTH
entities.description: Helminth is a backdoor with variants delivered via Excel macros and as a standalone Windows executable.

entities.name: MILAN
entities.description: Milan is a backdoor implant based on DanBot, used by HEXANE since at least June 2020.

entities.name: HERMETICWIPER
entities.description: HermeticWiper is a data wiper used primarily against Ukraine, targeting various sectors including government and IT services.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a Trojan spyware program written in C++ that emerged in September 2016 as a successor to Dyre.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, is a Russian cyber espionage group believed to be associated with the Russian government, known for using tools like GoldMax.

entities.name: SOLARWINDS COMPROMISE
entities.description: The SolarWinds Compromise refers to a significant cyber attack that involved the exploitation of vulnerabilities in the SolarWinds software, impacting numerous organizations globally.

entities.name: NORTH KOREAN CAMPAIGNS
entities.description: North Korean campaigns refer to various cyber operations conducted by North Korean state-sponsored groups, often involving malware like BabyShark.

ESET Hermetic Wiper February 2022)(Citation: Qualys Hermetic Wiper March 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TrickBot
Software description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) is a Trojan spyware program written in C++ that first emerged in September 2016 as a possible successor to [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024). [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) was developed and initially used by [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) for targeting banking sites in North America, Australia, and throughout Europe; it has since been used against all sectors worldwide as part of "big game hunting" ransomware campaigns.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)(Citation: IBM TrickBot Nov 2016)(Citation: CrowdStrike Wizard Spider October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Carbon
Software description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) is a sophisticated, second-stage backdoor and framework that can be used to steal sensitive information from victims. [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) has been selectively used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)(Citation: Securelist Turla Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: JHUHUGIT
Software description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: yty
Software description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) is a modular, plugin-based malware framework. The components of the framework are written in a variety of programming languages. (Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sibot
Software description: [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) is dual-purpose malware written in VBScript designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system as well as download and execute additional payloads. Microsoft discovered three [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) variants in early 2021 during its investigation of [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) and the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024).(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Anchor
Software description: [Anchor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0504) is one of a family of backdoor malware that has been used in conjunction with [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) on selected high profile targets since at least 2018.(Citation: Cyberreason Anchor December 2019)(Citation: Medium Anchor DNS July 2020)
Platforms: Linux, Windows

Software name: GrimAgent
Software description: [GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) is a backdoor that has been used before the deployment of [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) ransomware since at least 2020; it is likely used by [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) and [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102).(Citation: Group IB GrimAgent July 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SVCReady
Software description: [SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) is a loader that has been used since at least April 2022 in malicious spam campaigns. Security researchers have noted overlaps between [TA551](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0127) activity and [SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) distribution, including similarities in file names, lure images, and identical grammatical errors.(Citation: HP SVCReady Jun 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Machete
Software description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) is a cyber espionage toolset used by [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0095). It is a Python-based backdoor targeting Windows machines that was first observed in 2010.(Citation: ESET Mach

entities.name: ESET
entities.description: ESET is a cybersecurity company known for its antivirus and security software solutions, including the detection of malware like Hermetic Wiper and TrickBot.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a Trojan spyware program that emerged in September 2016, initially targeting banking sites and has since been used in ransomware campaigns worldwide.

entities.name: WIZARD SPIDER
entities.description: Wizard Spider is a cybercriminal group known for developing and deploying malware such as TrickBot and is involved in various cybercrime activities.

entities.name: CARBON
entities.description: Carbon is a sophisticated backdoor and framework used to steal sensitive information, selectively employed by the Turla group against government organizations.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber espionage group known for its advanced persistent threat (APT) activities, particularly targeting government and foreign affairs-related organizations.

entities.name: COMRAT
entities.description: ComRAT is a second-stage implant used by the Turla group, suspected to be a descendant of Agent.btz, and has undergone significant development since its first identification in 2007.

entities.name: JHUHUGIT
entities.description: JHUHUGIT is malware used by APT28, based on Carberp source code, serving reconnaissance purposes in cyber operations.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28, also known as Sofacy, is a Russian cyber espionage group known for targeting government and military organizations.

entities.name: SIBOT
entities.description: Sibot is dual-purpose malware designed for persistence on compromised systems and to download additional payloads, discovered during investigations of APT29.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, is a Russian cyber espionage group known for its sophisticated attacks against various sectors, including government and private organizations.

entities.name: ANCHOR
entities.description: Anchor is a family of backdoor malware used in conjunction with TrickBot on high-profile targets since at least 2018.

entities.name: GRIMAGENT
entities.description: GrimAgent is a backdoor used before the deployment of Ryuk ransomware, likely associated with the FIN6 and Wizard Spider groups.

entities.name: FIN6
entities.description: FIN6 is a cybercriminal group known for its involvement in ransomware attacks and other cybercrime activities.

entities.name: SVCREADY
entities.description: SVCReady is a loader used in malicious spam campaigns since at least April 2022, with overlaps noted with TA551 activity.

entities.name: TA551
entities.description: TA551 is a cybercriminal group known for its involvement in spam campaigns and distribution of malware.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that is commonly targeted by various types of malware, including TrickBot and Hermetic Wiper.

entities.name: MACHETE
entities.description:
Machete is a cyber espionage toolset used by the Machete group, targeting Windows machines since 2010.
Machete is a cybercriminal group known for its cyber espionage activities, particularly targeting Latin American countries.
