Platforms: Windows

Software name: Machete
Software description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) is a cyber espionage toolset used by [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0095). It is a Python-based backdoor targeting Windows machines that was first observed in 2010.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)(Citation: 360 Machete Sep 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SharpStage
Software description: [SharpStage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0546) is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.(Citation: Cybereason Molerats Dec 2020)(Citation: BleepingComputer Molerats Dec 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NotPetya
Software description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) in a worldwide attack starting on June 27, 2017. While [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) appears as a form of ransomware, its main purpose was to destroy data and disk structures on compromised systems; the attackers never intended to make the encrypted data recoverable. As such, [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) may be more appropriately thought of as a form of wiper malware. [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploits EternalBlue and EternalRomance.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)(Citation: ESET Telebots June 2017)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: zwShell
Software description: [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) is a remote access tool (RAT) written in Delphi that has been seen in the wild since the spring of 2010 and used by threat actors during [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002).(Citation: McAfee Night Dragon)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remexi
Software description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) is a Windows-based Trojan that was developed in the C programming language.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Prestige
Software description: [Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) ransomware has been used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least March 2022, including against transportation and related logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland in October 2022.(Citation: Microsoft Prestige ransomware October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BADHATCH
Software description: [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) is a backdoor that has been utilized by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) since at least 2019. [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) has been used to target the insurance, retail, technology, and chemical industries in the United States, Canada, South Africa, Panama, and Italy.(Citation: Gigamon BADHATCH Jul 2019)(Citation: BitDefender BADHATCH Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dridex
Software description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) is a prolific banking Trojan that first appeared in 2014. By December 2019, the US Treasury estimated [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) had infected computers in hundreds of banks and financial institutions in over 40 countries, leading to more than $100 million in theft. [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) was created from the source code of the Bugat banking Trojan (also known as Cridex).(Citation: Dell Dridex Oct 2015)(Citation: Kaspersky Dridex May 2017)(Citation: Treasury EvilCorp Dec 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Okrum
Software description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004).(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ramsay
Software description: [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) is an information stealing malware framework designed to collect and exfiltrate sensitive documents, including from air-gapped systems. Researchers have identified overlaps between [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) and the [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012)-associated Retro malware.(Citation: Eset Ramsay May 2020)(Citation: Antiy CERT Ramsay April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: MACHETE
entities.description: Machete is a cyber espionage toolset used by a group known as Machete, targeting Windows machines since 2010.

entities.name: SHARPSAGE
entities.description: SharpStage is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities, used in cyber attacks.

entities.name: NOTPETYA
entities.description: NotPetya is malware used by the Sandworm Team in a worldwide attack starting on June 27, 2017, primarily aimed at destroying data.

entities.name: SANDWORM TEAM
entities.description: Sandworm Team is a hacking group responsible for the NotPetya malware attack.

entities.name: ZWSHELL
entities.description: zwShell is a remote access tool (RAT) used by threat actors during the Night Dragon campaign.

entities.name: REMEXI
entities.description: Remexi is a Windows-based Trojan developed in the C programming language.

entities.name: PRESTIGE
entities.description: Prestige ransomware has been used by Sandworm Team since at least March 2022, targeting transportation and logistics industries.

entities.name: BADHATCH
entities.description: BADHATCH is a backdoor utilized by FIN8 since at least 2019, targeting various industries across multiple countries.

entities.name: DRIDEX
entities.description: Dridex is a banking Trojan that has infected computers in hundreds of banks and financial institutions globally since 2014.

entities.name: OKRUM
entities.description: Okrum is a Windows backdoor linked to the Ke3chang group, seen in use since December 2016.

entities.name: RAMSAY
entities.description: Ramsay is an information stealing malware framework designed to collect sensitive documents, including from air-gapped systems.

entities.name: NIGHT DRAGON
entities.description: Night Dragon is a cyber campaign during which zwShell was utilized as a remote access tool by threat actors.

entities.name: KE3CHANG
entities.description: Ke3chang is a hacking group associated with various cyber espionage activities, including the use of Okrum malware.

entities.name: DARKHOTEL
entities.description: Darkhotel is a cyber espionage group known for targeting high-profile individuals and organizations, associated with the Retro malware.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
and exfiltrate sensitive documents, including from air-gapped systems. Researchers have identified overlaps between [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) and the [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012)-associated Retro malware.(Citation: Eset Ramsay May 2020)(Citation: Antiy CERT Ramsay April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Crutch
Software description: [Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) is a backdoor designed for document theft that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2015.(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Tomiris
Software description: [Tomiris](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0671) is a backdoor written in Go that continuously queries its C2 server for executables to download and execute on a victim system. It was first reported in September 2021 during an investigation of a successful DNS hijacking campaign against a Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) member. Security researchers assess there are similarities between [Tomiris](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0671) and [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588).(Citation: Kaspersky Tomiris Sep 2021)
Platforms: None

Software name: Bad Rabbit
Software description: [Bad Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0606) is a self-propagating ransomware that affected the Ukrainian transportation sector in 2017. [Bad Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0606) has also targeted organizations and consumers in Russia. (Citation: Secure List Bad Rabbit)(Citation: ESET Bad Rabbit)(Citation: Dragos IT ICS Ransomware) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: IcedID
Software description: [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information that has been observed in the wild since at least 2017.  [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483)  has been downloaded by [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) in multiple campaigns.(Citation: IBM IcedID November 2017)(Citation: Juniper IcedID June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SharpDisco
Software description: [SharpDisco](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1089) is a dropper developed in C# that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2020 to load malicious plugins.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BADNEWS
Software description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is malware that has been used by the actors responsible for the [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) campaign. Its name was given due to its use of RSS feeds, forums, and blogs for command and control. (Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon) (Citation: TrendMicro Patchwork Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dyre
Software description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) is a banking Trojan that has been used for financial gain. 
 (Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ZxxZ
Software description: [ZxxZ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1013) is a trojan written in Visual C++ that has been used by [BITTER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1002) since at least August 2021, including against Bangladeshi government personnel.(Citation: Cisco Talos Bitter Bangladesh May 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Lucifer
Software description: [Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) is a crypto miner and DDoS hybrid malware that leverages well-known exploits to spread laterally on Windows platforms.(Citation: Unit 42 Lucifer June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Saint Bot
Software description: [Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) is a .NET downloader that has been used by [Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) since at least March 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Saint Bot April 2021)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 OutSteel SaintBot February 2022 )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GravityRAT
Software description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) is a remote access tool (RAT) and has been in ongoing development since 2016. The actor behind the tool remains unknown, but two usernames have been recovered that link to the author, which are "TheMartian" and "The Invincible." According to the National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India, the malware has been identified in attacks against organization and entities in India. (Citation: Talos GravityRAT)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SoreFang
Software description: [SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) is first stage downloader used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) for exfiltration and to load other malware.(

entities.name: DARKHOTEL
entities.description: Darkhotel is a group associated with cyber attacks, known for its Retro malware.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a hacking group that has been using the Crutch backdoor for document theft since at least 2015.

entities.name: TOMIRIS
entities.description: Tomiris is a backdoor malware that queries its C2 server for executables, first reported in September 2021.

entities.name: BAD RABBIT
entities.description: Bad Rabbit is a self-propagating ransomware that affected the Ukrainian transportation sector in 2017.

entities.name: ICEDID
entities.description: IcedID is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information, observed since at least 2017.

entities.description: SharpDisco is a dropper developed in C# used by MoustachedBouncer to load malicious plugins since at least 2020.

entities.name: BADNEWS
entities.description: BADNEWS is malware used by the actors responsible for the Patchwork campaign, utilizing RSS feeds for command and control.

entities.name: DYRE
entities.description: Dyre is a banking Trojan used for financial gain, active since at least 2015.

entities.name: ZXXZ
entities.description: ZxxZ is a trojan used by BITTER against Bangladeshi government personnel since at least August 2021.

entities.name: LUCIFER
entities.description: Lucifer is a crypto miner and DDoS hybrid malware that spreads laterally on Windows platforms.

entities.description: Saint Bot is a .NET downloader used by Ember Bear since at least March 2021.

entities.name: GRAVITYRAT
entities.description: GravityRAT is a remote access tool in ongoing development since 2016, linked to attacks against organizations in India.

entities.name: SOREFANG
entities.description: SoreFang is a first stage downloader used by APT29 for exfiltration and to load other malware.

entities.name: GOLDMAX
entities.description: GoldMax is a malware that has been assessed to have similarities with Tomiris, indicating a relationship in malware development.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a malware strain that has been involved in multiple campaigns, including downloading IcedID.

entities.name: PATCHWORK
entities.description: Patchwork is a cyber campaign associated with the use of BADNEWS malware for command and control.

entities.name: BITTER
entities.description: BITTER is a hacking group that has used ZxxZ against Bangladeshi government personnel.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group known for using SoreFang as a first stage downloader for exfiltration and loading other malware.

chunk:
to the National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India, the malware has been identified in attacks against organization and entities in India. (Citation: Talos GravityRAT)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SoreFang
Software description: [SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) is first stage downloader used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) for exfiltration and to load other malware.(Citation: NCSC APT29 July 2020)(Citation: CISA SoreFang July 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BONDUPDATER
Software description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). It was first observed in November 2017 during targeting of a Middle Eastern government organization, and an updated version was observed in August 2018 being used to target a government organization with spearphishing emails.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig Sep 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Lokibot
Software description: [Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) is a widely distributed information stealer that was first reported in 2015. It is designed to steal sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, cryptocurrency wallets, and other credentials. [Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) can also create a backdoor into infected systems to allow an attacker to install additional payloads.(Citation: Infoblox Lokibot January 2019)(Citation: Morphisec Lokibot April 2020)(Citation: CISA Lokibot September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Meteor
Software description: [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is a wiper that was used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, the Ministry of Roads, and Urban Development systems, in July 2021. [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is likely a newer version of similar wipers called Stardust and Comet that were reportedly used by a group called "Indra" since at least 2019 against private companies in Syria.(Citation: Check Point Meteor Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Tarrask
Software description: [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) is malware that has been used by [HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) since at least August 2021. [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) was designed to evade digital defenses and maintain persistence by generating concealed scheduled tasks.(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RTM
Software description: [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) is custom malware written in Delphi. It is used by the group of the same name ([RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048)). Newer versions of the malware have been reported publicly as Redaman.(Citation: ESET RTM Feb 2017)(Citation: Unit42 Redaman January 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SUGARDUMP
Software description: [SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) is a proprietary browser credential harvesting tool that was used by UNC3890 during the [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010) campaign. The first known [SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) version was used since at least early 2021, a second SMTP C2 version was used from late 2021-early 2022, and a third HTTP C2 variant was used since at least April 2022.(Citation: Mandiant UNC3890 Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Shamoon
Software description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) is wiper malware that was first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice" in 2012. Other versions known as Shamoon 2 and Shamoon 3 were observed in 2016 and 2018. [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has also been seen leveraging [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) and Filerase to carry out data wiping tasks. Analysis has linked [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) with [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) based on multiple shared artifacts and coding patterns.(Citation: Cylera Kwampirs 2022) The term Shamoon is sometimes used to refer to the group using the malware as well as the malware itself.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 201

entities.name: NATIONAL COMPUTER EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAM
entities.description: The National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India is responsible for responding to cybersecurity incidents and providing guidance on malware threats in India.

entities.name: INDIA
entities.description: India is a country that has been targeted by malware attacks, as reported by CERT.

entities.name: SOREFANG
entities.description: SoreFang is a first stage downloader used by APT29 for exfiltration and to load other malware.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group known for its sophisticated attacks and use of malware like SoreFang.

entities.name: BONDUPDATER
entities.description: BONDUPDATER is a PowerShell backdoor used by OilRig, targeting government organizations.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a hacking group that has been involved in cyber attacks against Middle Eastern government organizations.

entities.name: LOKIBOT
entities.description: Lokibot is an information stealer designed to steal sensitive information and create backdoors into infected systems.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a modular malware variant primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants.

entities.name: METEOR
entities.description: Meteor is a wiper malware used against Iranian government organizations.

entities.name: TARRASK
entities.description: Tarrask is malware used by HAFNIUM to evade digital defenses and maintain persistence.

entities.name: RTM
entities.description: RTM is custom malware used by the group of the same name, known for its sophisticated coding.

entities.name: SUGARDUMP
entities.description: SUGARDUMP is a browser credential harvesting tool used by UNC3890 during specific cyber campaigns.

entities.name: SHAMOON
entities.description: Shamoon is wiper malware first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice."

entities.name: HAFNIUM
entities.description: HAFNIUM is a group known for its cyber attacks, particularly against organizations in the United States and other countries.

entities.name: UNC3890
entities.description: UNC3890 is a cyber threat actor known for using various malware tools in their campaigns.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is the operating system platform on which various malware, including those mentioned, operates.

chunk:
ilerase to carry out data wiping tasks. Analysis has linked [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) with [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) based on multiple shared artifacts and coding patterns.(Citation: Cylera Kwampirs 2022) The term Shamoon is sometimes used to refer to the group using the malware as well as the malware itself.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Agent Tesla
Software description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) is a spyware Trojan written for the .NET framework that has been observed since at least 2014.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Attor
Software description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been seen in use since 2013. [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a loadable plugin architecture to customize functionality for specific targets.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ryuk
Software description: [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) is a ransomware designed to target enterprise environments that has been used in attacks since at least 2018. [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) shares code similarities with Hermes ransomware.(Citation: CrowdStrike Ryuk January 2019)(Citation: FireEye Ryuk and Trickbot January 2019)(Citation: FireEye FIN6 Apr 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EvilBunny
Software description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) is a C++ malware sample observed since 2011 that was designed to be a execution platform for Lua scripts.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Maze
Software description: [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) ransomware, previously known as "ChaCha", was discovered in May 2019. In addition to encrypting files on victim machines for impact, [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) operators conduct information stealing campaigns prior to encryption and post the information online to extort affected companies.(Citation: FireEye Maze May 2020)(Citation: McAfee Maze March 2020)(Citation: Sophos Maze VM September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RemoteCMD
Software description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) is a custom tool used by [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) to execute commands on a remote system similar to SysInternal's PSEXEC functionality. (Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AppleJeus
Software description: [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) is a family of downloaders initially discovered in 2018 embedded within trojanized cryptocurrency applications. [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032), targeting companies in the energy, finance, government, industry, technology, and telecommunications sectors, and several countries including the United States, United Kingdom, South Korea, Australia, Brazil, New Zealand, and Russia. [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has been used to distribute the [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) RAT.(Citation: CISA AppleJeus Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: CozyCar
Software description: [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. It is a modular malware platform, and its backdoor component can be instructed to download and execute a variety of modules with different functionality. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RainyDay
Software description: [RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) is a backdoor tool that has been used by [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) since at least 2020.(Citation: Bitdefender Naikon April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ccf32
Software description: [ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) is data collection malware that has been used since at least February 2019, most notably during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign; there is also a similar x64 version.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWERSTATS
Software description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069

entities.name: SHAMOON
entities.description: Shamoon is a malware associated with cyber attacks, often linked to a group using the malware for malicious purposes.

entities.name: KWAMPIRS
entities.description: Kwampirs is a malware that has been linked to Shamoon based on shared artifacts and coding patterns.

entities.name: AGENT TESLA
entities.description: Agent Tesla is a spyware Trojan that has been observed since at least 2014, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: ATTOR
entities.description: Attor is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been in use since 2013, featuring a loadable plugin architecture.

entities.name: RYUK
entities.description: Ryuk is a ransomware designed for enterprise environments, used in attacks since at least 2018, sharing code similarities with Hermes ransomware.

entities.name: EVILBUNNY
entities.description: EvilBunny is a C++ malware sample designed to execute Lua scripts, observed since 2011.

entities.name: MAZE
entities.description: Maze is a ransomware that encrypts files and conducts information stealing campaigns, discovered in May 2019.

entities.name: REMOTECMD
entities.description: RemoteCMD is a custom tool used by APT3 to execute commands on remote systems.

entities.name: APPLEJEUS
entities.description: AppleJeus is a family of downloaders embedded in trojanized cryptocurrency applications, used by Lazarus Group since 2018.

entities.name: COZYCAR
entities.description: CozyCar is malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, featuring a modular platform for various functionalities.

entities.name: RAINYDAY
entities.description: RainyDay is a backdoor tool used by Naikon since at least 2020.

entities.name: CCF32
entities.description: ccf32 is data collection malware used since February 2019, notably during the FunnyDream campaign.

entities.name: POWERSTATS
entities.description: POWERSTATS is a PowerShell-based backdoor used by MuddyWater.

entities.name: LAZARUS GROUP
entities.description: Lazarus Group is a cybercrime group that has used AppleJeus to target various sectors including finance and technology.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a hacking group that utilized CozyCar malware from 2010 to 2015.

entities.name: NAIKON
entities.description: Naikon is a cyber espionage group that has been using RainyDay as a backdoor tool since at least 2020.

entities.name: MUDDYWATER
entities.description: MuddyWater is a hacking group known for using POWERSTATS as a PowerShell-based backdoor.

chunk:
notably during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign; there is also a similar x64 version.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWERSTATS
Software description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069). (Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Duqu
Software description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) is a malware platform that uses a modular approach to extend functionality after deployment within a target network. (Citation: Symantec W32.Duqu)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BackConfig
Software description: [BackConfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0475) is a custom Trojan with a flexible plugin architecture that has been used by [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040).(Citation: Unit 42 BackConfig May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NETWIRE
Software description: [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: McAfee Netwire Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: SQLRat
Software description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) is malware that executes SQL scripts to avoid leaving traditional host artifacts. [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has been observed using it.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)
Platforms: None

Software name: OopsIE
Software description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) is a Trojan used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) to remotely execute commands as well as upload/download files to/from victims. (Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bumblebee
Software description: [Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) is a custom loader written in C++ that has been used by multiple threat actors, including possible initial access brokers, to download and execute additional payloads since at least March 2022. [Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has been linked to ransomware operations including [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575), Quantum, and Mountlocker and derived its name from the appearance of "bumblebee" in the user-agent.(Citation: Google EXOTIC LILY March 2022)(Citation: Proofpoint Bumblebee April 2022)(Citation: Symantec Bumblebee June 2022)

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bazar
Software description: [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) is a downloader and backdoor that has been used since at least April 2020, with infections primarily against professional services, healthcare, manufacturing, IT, logistics and travel companies across the US and Europe. [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) reportedly has ties to [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) campaigns and can be used to deploy additional malware, including ransomware, and to steal sensitive data.(Citation: Cybereason Bazar July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Matryoshka
Software description: [Matryoshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) is a malware framework used by [CopyKittens](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0052) that consists of a dropper, loader, and RAT. It has multiple versions; v1 was seen in the wild from July 2016 until January 2017. v2 has fewer commands and other minor differences. (Citation: ClearSky Wilted Tulip July 2017) (Citation: CopyKittens Nov 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GRIFFON
Software description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) is a JavaScript backdoor used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046). (Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ServHelper
Software description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) is a backdoor first observed in late 2018. The backdoor is written in Delphi and is typically delivered as a DLL file.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Disco
Software description: [Disco](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1088) is a custom implant that has been used

entities.name: FUNNYDREAM
entities.description: The FunnyDream campaign is a cyber attack campaign that has been documented and analyzed for its impact and methods.

entities.name: POWERSTATS
entities.description: POWERSTATS is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by the MuddyWater group for cyber operations.

entities.name: MUDDYWATER
entities.description: MuddyWater is a cyber threat group known for its use of PowerShell-based malware, including POWERSTATS.

entities.name: VALAK
entities.description: Valak is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019.

entities.name: DUQU
entities.description: Duqu is a malware platform that uses a modular approach to extend functionality after deployment within a target network.

entities.name: BACKCONFIG
entities.description: BackConfig is a custom Trojan with a flexible plugin architecture that has been used by the Patchwork group.

entities.name: PATCHWORK
entities.description: Patchwork is a cyber threat group known for its use of the BackConfig Trojan in cyber attacks.

entities.name: NETWIRE
entities.description: NETWIRE is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) used by various criminal and APT groups.

entities.name: FIN7
entities.description: FIN7 is a cyber criminal group known for its sophisticated attacks and use of various malware, including SQLRat and GRIFFON.

entities.name: SQLRAT
entities.description: SQLRat is malware that executes SQL scripts to avoid leaving traditional host artifacts, used by the FIN7 group.

entities.name: OOPSIE
entities.description: OopsIE is a Trojan used by the OilRig group to remotely execute commands and manage files on victims' systems.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a cyber threat group known for its use of the OopsIE Trojan in cyber operations.

entities.name: BUMBLEBEE
entities.description: Bumblebee is a custom loader used by multiple threat actors to download and execute additional payloads, linked to ransomware operations.

entities.name: CONTIN
entities.description: Conti is a ransomware group that has been linked to various cyber attacks and operations.

entities.name: BAZAR
entities.description: Bazar is a downloader and backdoor used primarily against professional services and healthcare sectors, with ties to TrickBot campaigns.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a cyber criminal group known for its malware and ransomware operations, including the Bazar malware.

entities.name: MATRYOSHKA
entities.description: Matryoshka is a malware framework used by the CopyKittens group, consisting of a dropper, loader, and RAT.

entities.name: COPYKITTENS
entities.description: CopyKittens is a cyber threat group known for its use of the Matryoshka malware framework in cyber attacks.

entities.name: GRIFFON
entities.description: GRIFFON is a JavaScript backdoor used by the FIN7 group for cyber operations.

entities.name: SERVHELPER
entities.description: ServHelper is a backdoor first observed in late 2018, typically delivered as a DLL file.

chunk:
Software name: ServHelper
Software description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) is a backdoor first observed in late 2018. The backdoor is written in Delphi and is typically delivered as a DLL file.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Disco
Software description: [Disco](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1088) is a custom implant that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2020 including in campaigns using targeted malicious content injection for initial access and command and control.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pteranodon
Software description: [Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) is a custom backdoor used by [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047). (Citation: Palo Alto Gamaredon Feb 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Stuxnet
Software description: [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was the first publicly reported piece of malware to specifically target industrial control systems devices. [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) is a large and complex piece of malware that utilized multiple different behaviors including multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, a sophisticated Windows rootkit, and network infection routines.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011)(Citation: CISA ICS Advisory ICSA-10-272-01)(Citation: ESET Stuxnet Under the Microscope)(Citation: Langer Stuxnet) [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was discovered in 2010, with some components being used as early as November 2008.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: InvisiMole
Software description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) is a modular spyware program that has been used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013. [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has two backdoor modules called RC2FM and RC2CL that are used to perform post-exploitation activities. It has been discovered on compromised victims in the Ukraine and Russia. [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) infrastructure has been used to download and execute [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) against a small number of victims.(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2018)(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CosmicDuke
Software description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWRUNER
Software description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server. (Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gazer
Software description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) is a backdoor used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2016. (Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ISMInjector
Software description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) is a Trojan used to install another [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049

entities.name: SERVHELPER
entities.description: ServHelper is a backdoor software first observed in late 2018, written in Delphi and typically delivered as a DLL file, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: DISCO
entities.description: Disco is a custom implant used by MoustachedBouncer since at least 2020, involved in campaigns using targeted malicious content injection for initial access and command and control, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: DARKWATCHMAN
entities.description: DarkWatchman is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) first observed in November 2021, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: PTERANODON
entities.description: Pteranodon is a custom backdoor used by Gamaredon Group, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: STUXNET
entities.description: Stuxnet is the first publicly reported malware specifically targeting industrial control systems, discovered in 2010, and known for its complex behaviors and multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: INVISIMOLE
entities.description: InvisiMole is a modular spyware program used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013, with two backdoor modules for post-exploitation activities, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: COSMICDUKE
entities.description: CosmicDuke is malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: QAKBOT
entities.description: QakBot is a modular banking trojan used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007, evolving from an information stealer to a delivery agent for ransomware, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: POWRUNER
entities.description: POWRUNER is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: REVENGE RAT
entities.description: Revenge RAT is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#), targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: GAZER
entities.description: Gazer is a backdoor used by Turla since at least 2016, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: GAMAREDON GROUP
entities.description: Gamaredon Group is a cyber threat actor known for using custom backdoors like Pteranodon and InvisiMole.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group that used CosmicDuke malware from 2010 to 2015.

entities.name: FINANCIALLY-MOTIVATED ACTORS
entities.description: Financially-motivated actors are individuals or groups that primarily engage in cybercrime for financial gain, using tools like QakBot.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber espionage group known for using backdoors like Gazer since at least 2016.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
itre.org/software/S0168) is a backdoor used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2016. (Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ISMInjector
Software description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) is a Trojan used to install another [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) backdoor, ISMAgent. (Citation: OilRig New Delivery Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Goopy
Software description: [Goopy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0477) is a Windows backdoor and Trojan used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) and shares several similarities to another backdoor used by the group ([Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354)). [Goopy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0477) is named for its impersonation of the legitimate Google Updater executable.(Citation: Cybereason Cobalt Kitty 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LitePower
Software description: [LitePower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0680) is a downloader and second stage malware that has been used by [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) since at least 2021.(Citation: Kaspersky WIRTE November 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Smoke Loader
Software description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) is a malicious bot application that can be used to load other malware.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) has been seen in the wild since at least 2011 and has included a number of different payloads. It is notorious for its use of deception and self-protection. It also comes with several plug-ins. (Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016) (Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zebrocy
Software description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) is a Trojan that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least November 2015. The malware comes in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, AutoIt, C#, VB.NET, and Golang. (Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: CISA Zebrocy Oct 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HotCroissant
Software description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed by U.S. government entities to malicious North Korean government cyber activity, tracked collectively as HIDDEN COBRA.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020) [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) shares numerous code similarities with [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433).(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QUADAGENT
Software description: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). (Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: TURNA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber threat group known for its sophisticated cyber espionage activities, utilizing various malware and backdoors since at least 2016.

entities.name: ISM INJECTOR
entities.description: ISMInjector is a Trojan used to install another backdoor, ISMAgent, and is associated with the Turla group.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a cyber threat group that has been active in cyber espionage and is known for using various malware, including ISMAgent and QUADAGENT.

entities.name: GOOPY
entities.description: Goopy is a Windows backdoor and Trojan used by APT32, known for its impersonation of the legitimate Google Updater executable.

entities.name: APT32
entities.description: APT32 is a cyber threat group that engages in cyber espionage and is known for using malware like Goopy.

entities.name: LITEPOWER
entities.description: LitePower is a downloader and second stage malware used by WIRTE since at least 2021.

entities.name: WIRTE
entities.description: WIRTE is a cyber threat group known for its use of malware like LitePower.

entities.name: SMOKE LOADER
entities.description: Smoke Loader is a malicious bot application that can load other malware and has been active since at least 2011.

entities.name: ZEBROCY
entities.description: Zebrocy is a Trojan used by APT28 since at least November 2015, available in several programming language variants.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a cyber threat group known for its sophisticated cyber espionage activities and the use of malware like Zebrocy.

entities.name: HOT CROISSANT
entities.description: HotCroissant is a remote access trojan attributed to North Korean government cyber activity, known collectively as HIDDEN COBRA.

entities.name: QUADAGENT
entities.description: QUADAGENT is a PowerShell backdoor used by OilRig.

chunk:
There are 4 software using the attack technique called RC Scripts. Their names are as follows:
* HiddenWasp
* Green Lambert
* Cyclops Blink
* iKitten

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: HiddenWasp
Software description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) is a Linux-based Trojan used to target systems for remote control. It comes in the form of a statically linked ELF binary with stdlibc++.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Green Lambert
Software description: [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) is a modular backdoor that security researchers assess has been used by an advanced threat group referred to as Longhorn and The Lamberts. First reported in 2017, the Windows variant of [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) may have been used as early as 2008; a macOS version was uploaded to a multiscanner service in September 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Lamberts Toolkit April 2017)(Citation: Objective See Green Lambert for OSX Oct 2021)  
Platforms: Windows, iOS, macOS, Linux

Software name: Cyclops Blink
Software description: [Cyclops Blink](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0687) is a modular malware that has been used in widespread campaigns by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least 2019 to target Small/Home Office (SOHO) network devices, including WatchGuard and Asus.(Citation: NCSC Cyclops Blink February 2022)(Citation: NCSC CISA Cyclops Blink Advisory February 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Cyclops Blink March 2022)
Platforms: Network

Software name: iKitten
Software description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) is a macOS exfiltration agent  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

entities.name: HIDDENWASP
entities.description: HiddenWasp is a Linux-based Trojan used to target systems for remote control, coming in the form of a statically linked ELF binary with stdlibc++.

entities.name: GREEN LAMBERT
entities.description: Green Lambert is a modular backdoor associated with an advanced threat group known as Longhorn and The Lamberts, with variants for Windows, iOS, macOS, and Linux.

entities.name: CYCLOPS BLINK
entities.description: Cyclops Blink is a modular malware used in campaigns by Sandworm Team to target Small/Home Office network devices.

entities.name: IKITTEN
entities.description: iKitten is a macOS exfiltration agent designed for data extraction from infected systems.

entities.name: LONGHORN
entities.description: Longhorn is an advanced threat group associated with the use of Green Lambert malware in cyber attacks.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform targeted by various malware, including HiddenWasp and Green Lambert.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform targeted by Green Lambert malware.

entities.name: IOS
entities.description: iOS is an operating system platform targeted by Green Lambert malware.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform targeted by both Green Lambert and iKitten malware.

entities.name: NETWORK
entities.description: Network devices are targeted by Cyclops Blink malware, which aims to compromise Small/Home Office devices.

chunk:
There are 2 software using the attack technique called Extra Window Memory Injection. Their names are as follows:
* Epic
* Power Loader

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Epic
Software description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) is a backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). (Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Power Loader
Software description: [Power Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0177) is modular code sold in the cybercrime market used as a downloader in malware families such as Carberp, Redyms and Gapz. (Citation: MalwareTech Power Loader Aug 2013) (Citation: WeLiveSecurity Gapz and Redyms Mar 2013)
Platforms: None

entities.name: EPIC
entities.description: Epic is a backdoor software used by the Turla group, operating on Windows platforms.

entities.name: POWER LOADER
entities.description: Power Loader is a modular code used as a downloader in various malware families, available in the cybercrime market, with no specific platforms listed.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a cybercriminal group known for using the Epic backdoor software in their attacks.

entities.name: KASPERSKY
entities.description: Kaspersky is a cybersecurity company that provided a citation regarding the use of Epic by the Turla group.

entities.name: MALWARETECH
entities.description: MalwareTech is a cybersecurity entity that provided a citation regarding the use of Power Loader in malware families.

entities.name: WELIVESECURITY
entities.description: WeLiveSecurity is a cybersecurity organization that provided a citation regarding the use of Power Loader in malware families.

chunk: There are 3 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle. Their names are as follows: * DHCP Spoofing * ARP Cache Poisoning * LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Adversary-in-the-Middle Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique to support follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040), [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002), or replay attacks ([Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212)). By abusing features of common networking protocols that can determine the flow of network traffic (e.g. ARP, DNS, LLMNR, etc.), adversaries may force a device to communicate through an adversary controlled system so they can collect information or perform additional actions.(Citation: Rapid7 MiTM Basics) For example, adversaries may manipulate victim DNS settings to enable other malicious activities such as preventing/redirecting users from accessing legitimate sites and/or pushing additional malware.(Citation: ttint_rat)(Citation: dns_changer_trojans)(Citation: ad_blocker_with_miner) Adversaries may also manipulate DNS and leverage their position in order to intercept user credentials, including access tokens ([Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)) and session cookies ([Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)).(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)(Citation: Token tactics) [Downgrade Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/010)s can also be used to establish an AiTM position, such as by negotiating a less secure, deprecated, or weaker version of communication protocol (SSL/TLS) or encryption algorithm.(Citation: mitm_tls_downgrade_att)(Citation: taxonomy_downgrade_att_tls)(Citation: tlseminar_downgrade_att) Adversaries may also leverage the AiTM position to attempt to monitor and/or modify traffic, such as in [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). Adversaries can setup a position similar to AiTM to prevent traffic from flowing to the appropriate destination, potentially to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) and/or in support of a [Network Denial of Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498). Platforms: Windows, macOS, Linux, Network Attack technique name: DHCP Spoofing Attack technique description: Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.(Citation: rfc2131) The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 1. The client broadcasts a `DISCOVER` message. 2. The server responds with an `OFFER` message, which includes an available network address. 3. The client broadcasts a `REQUEST` message, which includes the network address offered. 4. The server acknowledges with an `ACK` message and the client receives the network configuration parameters. Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.(Citation: new_rogue_DHCP_serv_malware)(Citation: w32.tidserv.g) Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network. DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a INFORMATION-REQUEST (code 11) message to the All_DHCP_Relay_Agents_and_Servers multicast address.(Citation: rfc3315) Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations. Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, [Service Exhaustion Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002)) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a network’s DHCP allocation pool. Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS Attack technique name: ARP Cache Poisoning Attack technique description: Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used to enable follow-on behaviors

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is a technique where adversaries position themselves between networked devices to intercept or manipulate communications.

entities.name: DHCP SPOOFING
entities.description: DHCP Spoofing is a technique where adversaries act as a malicious DHCP server to redirect network traffic and collect sensitive information.

entities.name: ARP CACHE POISONING
entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is a technique where adversaries poison ARP caches to intercept communications between networked devices.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by various attack techniques including Adversary-in-the-Middle, DHCP Spoofing, and ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can be targeted by various attack techniques including Adversary-in-the-Middle, DHCP Spoofing, and ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that can be targeted by various attack techniques including Adversary-in-the-Middle, DHCP Spoofing, and ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: TRANSMITTED DATA MANIPULATION
entities.description: Transmitted Data Manipulation is a technique where adversaries alter data being transmitted over a network to achieve malicious objectives.

entities.name: REPLAY ATTACKS
entities.description: Replay Attacks involve intercepting and reusing valid data transmissions to gain unauthorized access or perform malicious actions.

entities.name: EXPLOITATION FOR CREDENTIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Exploitation for Credential Access is a technique where adversaries attempt to steal user credentials through various means, including interception.

entities.name: STEAL APPLICATION ACCESS TOKEN
entities.description: Steal Application Access Token is a technique where adversaries capture access tokens to gain unauthorized access to applications.

entities.name: STEAL WEB SESSION COOKIE
entities.description: Steal Web Session Cookie is a technique where adversaries capture session cookies to hijack user sessions.

entities.name: DOWGRADE ATTACK
entities.description: Downgrade Attack is a technique where adversaries force a system to use a less secure version of a protocol to exploit vulnerabilities.

entities.name: IMPAIR DEFENSES
entities.description: Impair Defenses is a technique where adversaries disrupt or disable security measures to facilitate their attacks.

entities.name: NETWORK DENIAL OF SERVICE
entities.description: Network Denial of Service is a technique where adversaries overwhelm a network to disrupt services and communications.

Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Attack technique name: ARP Cache Poisoning
Attack technique description: Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used to enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002).

The ARP protocol is used to resolve IPv4 addresses to link layer addresses, such as a media access control (MAC) address.(Citation: RFC826 ARP) Devices in a local network segment communicate with each other by using link layer addresses. If a networked device does not have the link layer address of a particular networked device, it may send out a broadcast ARP request to the local network to translate the IP address to a MAC address. The device with the associated IP address directly replies with its MAC address. The networked device that made the ARP request will then use as well as store that information in its ARP cache.

An adversary may passively wait for an ARP request to poison the ARP cache of the requesting device. The adversary may reply with their MAC address, thus deceiving the victim by making them believe that they are communicating with the intended networked device. For the adversary to poison the ARP cache, their reply must be faster than the one made by the legitimate IP address owner. Adversaries may also send a gratuitous ARP reply that maliciously announces the ownership of a particular IP address to all the devices in the local network segment.

The ARP protocol is stateless and does not require authentication. Therefore, devices may wrongly add or update the MAC address of the IP address in their ARP cache.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

Adversaries may use ARP cache poisoning as a means to intercept network traffic. This activity may be used to collect and/or relay data such as credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)

Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Attack technique name: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay
Attack technique description: By responding to LLMNR/NBT-NS network traffic, adversaries may spoof an authoritative source for name resolution to force communication with an adversary controlled system. This activity may be used to collect or relay authentication materials. 

Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR) and NetBIOS Name Service (NBT-NS) are Microsoft Windows components that serve as alternate methods of host identification. LLMNR is based upon the Domain Name System (DNS) format and allows hosts on the same local link to perform name resolution for other hosts. NBT-NS identifies systems on a local network by their NetBIOS name. (Citation: Wikipedia LLMNR)(Citation: TechNet NetBIOS)

Adversaries can spoof an authoritative source for name resolution on a victim network by responding to LLMNR (UDP 5355)/NBT-NS (UDP 137) traffic as if they know the identity of the requested host, effectively poisoning the service so that the victims will communicate with the adversary controlled system. If the requested host belongs to a resource that requires identification/authentication, the username and NTLMv2 hash will then be sent to the adversary controlled system. The adversary can then collect the hash information sent over the wire through tools that monitor the ports for traffic or through [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) and crack the hashes offline through [Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) to obtain the plaintext passwords.

In some cases where an adversary has access to a system that is in the authentication path between systems or when automated scans that use credentials attempt to authenticate to an adversary controlled system, the NTLMv1/v2 hashes can be intercepted and relayed to access and execute code against a target system. The relay step can happen in conjunction with poisoning but may also be independent of it.(Citation: byt3bl33d3r NTLM Relaying)(Citation: Secure Ideas SMB Relay) Additionally, adversaries may encapsulate the NTLMv1/v2 hashes into various protocols, such as LDAP, SMB, MSSQL and HTTP, to expand and use multiple services with the valid NTLM response. 

Several tools may be used to poison name services within local networks such as NBNSpoof, Metasploit, and [Responder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0174).(Citation: GitHub NBNSpoof)(Citation: Rapid7 LLMNR Spoofer)(Citation: GitHub Responder)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: ARP CACHE POISONING
entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is an attack technique where adversaries poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to intercept network traffic between devices.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING AND SMB RELAY
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay is an attack technique that allows adversaries to spoof name resolution and collect authentication materials by responding to network traffic.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that can be affected by various network attacks including ARP Cache Poisoning and LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that is susceptible to LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay attacks.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can be impacted by ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: NETWORK SNIFFING
entities.description: Network Sniffing is a technique used by adversaries to capture and analyze network traffic, often to collect sensitive information such as credentials.

entities.name: TRANSMITTED DATA MANIPULATION
entities.description: Transmitted Data Manipulation refers to the act of altering data being sent over a network, which can be used to deceive or exploit users.

entities.name: NTLMV1/V2
entities.description: NTLMv1/v2 are authentication protocols used in Windows environments that can be intercepted and exploited during network attacks.

entities.name: LDAP
entities.description: Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is a protocol used to access and manage directory information services, which can be targeted in network attacks.

entities.name: SMB
entities.description: Server Message Block (SMB) is a network file sharing protocol that can be exploited during attacks such as SMB Relay.

entities.name: MSSQL
entities.description: Microsoft SQL Server (MSSQL) is a relational database management system that can be targeted in network attacks involving NTLM authentication.

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Brute Ratel C4
Software description: [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool that first appeared in December 2020. [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was specifically designed to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) capabilities, and deploys agents called badgers to enable arbitrary command execution for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and persistence. In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July 2022)(Citation: MDSec Brute Ratel August 2022)(Citation: SANS Brute Ratel October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Black Basta October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms

entities.description: PoshC2 is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub, primarily focused on Windows implantation but also supports Linux/macOS.

entities.name: POWERSPLIT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of PowerShell modules and scripts for penetration testing tasks.

entities.name: SILENTTRINITY
entities.description: SILENTTRINITY is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python, used in cyber campaigns against government agencies.

entities.name: BRUTE RATEL C4
