chunk:
.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: CrackMapExec
Software description: [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488), or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python and designed for penetration testing against networks. [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) collects Active Directory information to conduct lateral movement through targeted networks.(Citation: CME Github September 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Sardonic
Software description: [Sardonic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1085) is a backdoor written in C and C++ that is known to be used by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061), as early as August 2021 to target a financial institution in the United States. [Sardonic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1085) has a plugin system that can load specially made DLLs and execute their functions.(Citation: Bitdefender Sardonic Aug 2021)(Citation: Symantec FIN8 Jul 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Meteor
Software description: [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is a wiper that was used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, the Ministry of Roads, and Urban Development systems, in July 2021. [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is likely a newer version of similar wipers called Stardust and Comet that were reportedly used by a group called "Indra" since at least 2019 against private companies in Syria.(Citation: Check Point Meteor Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RogueRobin
Software description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) is a payload used by [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) that has been developed in PowerShell and C#. (Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SUNBURST
Software description: [SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) is a trojanized DLL designed to fit within the SolarWinds Orion software update framework. It was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least February 2020.(Citation: SolarWinds Sunburst Sunspot Update January 2021)(Citation: Microsoft Deep Dive Solorigate January 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BlackEnergy
Software description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) is a malware toolkit that has been used by both criminal and APT actors. It dates back to at least 2007 and was originally designed to create botnets for use in conducting Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, but its use has evolved to support various plug-ins. It is well known for being used during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008, as well as in targeting Ukrainian institutions. Variants include BlackEnergy 2 and BlackEnergy 3. (Citation: F-Secure BlackEnergy 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FunnyDream
Software description: [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) is a backdoor with multiple components that was used during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign since at least 2019, primarily for execution and exfiltration.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283

entities.name: KOADIC
entities.description: Koadic is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub, offering options for staging payloads and creating implants.

entities.name: EMPIRE
entities.description: Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework available on GitHub, primarily written in Python with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell and Python.

entities.name: CRACKMAPEXEC
entities.description: CrackMapExec, or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python for penetration testing against networks, designed to collect Active Directory information for lateral movement.

entities.name: IMPACKET
entities.description: Impacket is an open source collection of Python modules for constructing and manipulating network protocols, containing tools for remote service execution and various network attacks.

entities.name: SARDONIC
entities.description: Sardonic is a backdoor written in C and C++ used by FIN8 to target financial institutions in the United States, featuring a plugin system for executing functions.

entities.name: METEOR
entities.description: Meteor is a wiper used against Iranian government organizations, likely a newer version of previous wipers, and associated with a group called "Indra."

entities.name: ROGUEROBIN
entities.description: RogueRobin is a payload developed in PowerShell and C# used by DarkHydrus.

entities.name: SUNBURST
entities.description: SUNBURST is a trojanized DLL used within the SolarWinds Orion software update framework, associated with APT29 since at least February 2020.

entities.name: BLACKENERGY
entities.description: BlackEnergy is a malware toolkit used by both criminal and APT actors, known for its role in DDoS attacks and targeting Ukrainian institutions.

entities.name: FUNNYDREAM
entities.description: FunnyDream is a backdoor used in the FunnyDream campaign for execution and exfiltration since at least 2019.

entities.name: JRAT
entities.description: jRAT is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a Russian cyber espionage group associated with the use of the SUNBURST malware in attacks against various organizations.

entities.name: DARKHYDRUS
entities.description: DarkHydrus is a cyber threat group known for using the RogueRobin payload in its operations.

entities.name: INDRA
entities.description: Indra is a group associated with the development and deployment of wiper malware, including Meteor, against Iranian targets.

</node>    <node id="ROGUEROBIN">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">RogueRobin is a payload developed in PowerShell and C# used by DarkHydrus.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="SUNBURST">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">SUNBURST is a trojanized DLL used within the SolarWinds Orion software update framework, associated with APT29 since at least February 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="BLACKENERGY">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">BlackEnergy is a malware toolkit used by both criminal and APT actors, known for its role in DDoS attacks and targeting Ukrainian institutions.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="FUNNYDREAM">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">FunnyDream is a backdoor used in the FunnyDream campaign for execution and exfiltration since at least 2019.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="JRAT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">jRAT is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="APT29">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">APT29 is a Russian cyber espionage group associated with the use of the SUNBURST malware in attacks against various organizations.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="DARKHYDRUS">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">DarkHydrus is a cyber threat group known for using the RogueRobin payload in its operations.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="INDRA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Indra is a group associated with the development and deployment of wiper malware, including Meteor, against Iranian targets.</data>      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <node id="FIN8">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </node>    <edge source="KOADIC" target="EMPIRE">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both Koadic and Empire are post-exploitation frameworks available on GitHub, used for penetration testing and remote administration.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="EMPIRE" target="CRACKMAPEXEC">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">Empire and CrackMapExec are both tools used for post-exploitation and penetration testing, with Empire being a framework and CrackMapExec focusing on network testing.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CRACKMAPEXEC" target="IMPACKET">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">CrackMapExec and Impacket are both tools used in penetration testing, with CrackMapExec focusing on Active Directory and Impacket on network protocol manipulation.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SARDONIC" target="SUNBURST">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Sardonic and SUNBURST are both malware tools associated with specific threat actors, with Sardonic used by FIN8 and SUNBURST linked to APT29.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SARDONIC" target="BLACKENERGY">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both BlackEnergy and Sardonic are malware tools used by threat actors, with BlackEnergy known for its historical use in DDoS attacks and Sardonic for targeting financial institutions.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SARDONIC" target="FIN8">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">Sardonic is a backdoor tool used by the FIN8 cybercriminal group to target financial institutions.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="METEOR" target="BLACKENERGY">      <data key="d3">3.0</data>      <data key="d4">Meteor and BlackEnergy are both malware tools used in cyber operations, with Meteor targeting Iranian organizations and BlackEnergy used in various attacks including against Ukraine.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="METEOR" target="INDRA">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Meteor is a wiper malware associated with the Indra group, targeting Iranian government organizations.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="ROGUEROBIN" target="DARKHYDRUS">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">RogueRobin is a payload developed and utilized by the DarkHydrus cyber threat group.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SUNBURST" target="APT29">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">SUNBURST is a malware tool used by APT29 in cyber espionage operations.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>    <edge source="FUNNYDREAM" target="JRAT">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">FunnyDream and jRAT are both backdoors used in cyber campaigns, with FunnyDream being used for execution and exfiltration and jRAT being a Java-based backdoor.</data>      <data key="d5">3af2e01ccb8a78d6263bbc36fb2717ed</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

Platforms: Windows

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) have been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform, similar to an online subscription model.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016) (Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FIVEHANDS
Software description: [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) is a customized version of [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) ransomware written in C++. [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) has been used since at least 2021, including in Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) campaigns, sometimes along with [SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615).(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)(Citation: NCC Group Fivehands June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zebrocy
Software description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) is a Trojan that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least November 2015. The malware comes in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, AutoIt, C#, VB.NET, and Golang. (Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: CISA Zebrocy Oct 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mosquito
Software description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) is a Win32 backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) is made up of three parts: the installer, the launcher, and the backdoor. The main backdoor is called CommanderDLL and is launched by the loader program. (Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Agent Tesla
Software description: [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) is a spyware Trojan written for the .NET framework that has been observed since at least 2014.(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018)(Citation: Bitdefender Agent Tesla April 2020)(Citation: Malwarebytes Agent Tesla April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bumblebee
Software description: [Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) is a custom loader written in C++ that has been used by multiple threat actors, including possible initial access brokers, to download and execute additional payloads since at least March 2022. [Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has been linked to ransomware operations including [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575), Quantum, and Mountlocker and derived its name from the appearance of "bumblebee" in the user-agent.(Citation: Google EXOTIC LILY March 2022)(Citation: Proofpoint Bumblebee April 2022)(Citation: Symantec Bumblebee June 2022)

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Action RAT
Software description: [Action RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1028) is a  remote access tool written in Delphi that has been used by [SideCopy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1008) since at least December 2021 against Indian and Afghani government personnel.(Citation: MalwareBytes SideCopy Dec 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EvilBunny
Software description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) is a C++ malware sample observed since 2011 that was designed to be a execution platform for Lua scripts.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Stuxnet
Software description: [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was the first publicly reported piece of malware to specifically target industrial control systems devices. [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) is a large and complex piece of malware that utilized multiple different behaviors including multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, a sophisticated Windows rootkit, and network infection routines.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Ch

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a modular malware variant primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants, first emerging in June 2014 and targeting the banking sector.

entities.name: FIVEHANDS
entities.description: FIVEHANDS is a customized version of DEATHRANSOM ransomware written in C++, used since at least 2021 in Ransomware-as-a-Service campaigns.

entities.name: ZEBROC
entities.description: Zebrocy is a Trojan used by APT28 since at least November 2015, available in several programming language variants.

entities.name: MOSQUITO
entities.description: Mosquito is a Win32 backdoor used by Turla, consisting of an installer, launcher, and backdoor component.

entities.description: Agent Tesla is a spyware Trojan written for the .NET framework, observed since at least 2014.

entities.name: BUMBLEBEE
entities.description: Bumblebee is a custom loader used by multiple threat actors to download and execute additional payloads since at least March 2022.

entities.name: ACTION RAT
entities.description: Action RAT is a remote access tool used by SideCopy against Indian and Afghani government personnel since at least December 2021.

chunk:
Stuxnet
Software description: [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was the first publicly reported piece of malware to specifically target industrial control systems devices. [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) is a large and complex piece of malware that utilized multiple different behaviors including multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, a sophisticated Windows rootkit, and network infection routines.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011)(Citation: CISA ICS Advisory ICSA-10-272-01)(Citation: ESET Stuxnet Under the Microscope)(Citation: Langer Stuxnet) [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was discovered in 2010, with some components being used as early as November 2008.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWRUNER
Software description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server. (Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SocGholish
Software description: [SocGholish](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1124) is a JavaScript-based loader malware that has been used since at least 2017. It has been observed in use against multiple sectors globally for initial access, primarily through drive-by-downloads masquerading as software updates. SocGholish is operated by [Mustard Tempest](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1020) and its access has been sold to groups including [Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) for downloading secondary RAT and ransomware payloads.(Citation: SentinelOne SocGholish Infrastructure November 2022)(Citation: SocGholish-update)(Citation: Red Canary SocGholish March 2024)(Citation: Secureworks Gold Prelude Profile) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FlawedAmmyy
Software description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first seen in early 2016. The code for [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) was based on leaked source code for a version of Ammyy Admin, a remote access software.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ProLock
Software description: [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) is a ransomware strain that has been used in Big Game Hunting (BGH) operations since at least 2020, often obtaining initial access with [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650). [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) is the successor to PwndLocker ransomware which was found to contain a bug allowing decryption without ransom payment in 2019.(Citation: Group IB Ransomware September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWERSTATS
Software description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069). (Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Akira
Software description: [Akira](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1129) ransomware, written in C++, is most prominently (but not exclusively) associated with the a ransomware-as-a-service entity [Akira](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1024).(Citation: Kersten Akira 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: OopsIE
Software description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) is a Trojan used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) to remotely execute commands as well as upload/download files to/from victims. (Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sibot
Software description: [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) is dual-purpose malware written in VBScript designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system as well as download and execute additional payloads. Microsoft discovered three [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) variants in early 2021 during its investigation of [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) and the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024).(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DustySky
Software description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) is multi-stage malware written in .NET that has been used by [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) since May 2015. (Citation: DustySky) (Citation: DustySky2)(Citation: Kaspersky MoleRATs April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: STUXNET
entities.description: Stuxnet is the first publicly reported piece of malware specifically targeting industrial control systems, discovered in 2010, utilizing multiple zero-day vulnerabilities and a sophisticated Windows rootkit.

entities.name: POWRUNER
entities.description: POWRUNER is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server, used in cyber operations.

entities.name: SOCGHOLISH
entities.description: SocGholish is a JavaScript-based loader malware used for initial access through drive-by-downloads, operated by Mustard Tempest since at least 2017.

entities.name: FLAWEDAMMYY
entities.description: FlawedAmmyy is a remote access tool (RAT) based on leaked source code for Ammyy Admin, first seen in early 2016.

entities.name: PROLOCK
entities.description: ProLock is a ransomware strain used in Big Game Hunting operations since at least 2020, often gaining access through QakBot.

entities.name: POWERSTATS
entities.description: POWERSTATS is a PowerShell-based backdoor used by MuddyWater for initial access in cyber attacks.

entities.name: AKIRA
entities.description: Akira is a ransomware written in C++ associated with a ransomware-as-a-service entity, first identified in 2023.

entities.name: OOPSIE
entities.description: OopsIE is a Trojan used by OilRig to execute commands remotely and manage files on victim systems.

entities.name: SIBOT
entities.description: Sibot is dual-purpose malware designed for persistence and downloading additional payloads, discovered during investigations of APT29.

entities.name: DUSTYSKY
entities.description: DustySky is multi-stage malware used by Molerats since May 2015, written in .NET.

entities.name: WANACRY
entities.description: WannaCry is ransomware that first appeared in a global attack in May 2017, affecting numerous systems worldwide.

entities.name: INDRIK SPIDER
entities.description: Indrik Spider is a cybercriminal group that has purchased access to SocGholish for deploying secondary malware payloads.

entities.name: MUDDYWATER
entities.description: MuddyWater is a cyber espionage group known for using POWERSTATS as a backdoor in their operations.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a cyber espionage group that utilizes OopsIE malware to execute commands and manage files on compromised systems.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group associated with the discovery of Sibot malware during investigations of their activities.

entities.name: MOLERATS
entities.description: Molerats is a cybercriminal group that has been using DustySky malware since May 2015 for various cyber operations.

Platforms: Windows

Software name: WannaCry
Software description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) is ransomware that was first seen in a global attack during May 2017, which affected more than 150 countries. It contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: US-CERT WannaCry 2017)(Citation: Washington Post WannaCry 2017)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EKANS
Software description: [EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) is ransomware variant written in Golang that first appeared in mid-December 2019 and has been used against multiple sectors, including energy, healthcare, and automotive manufacturing, which in some cases resulted in significant operational disruptions. [EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) has used a hard-coded kill-list of processes, including some associated with common ICS software platforms (e.g., GE Proficy, Honeywell HMIWeb, etc), similar to those defined in [MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576).(Citation: Dragos EKANS)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 EKANS)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RATANKBA
Software description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) is a remote controller tool used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines. (Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA) (Citation: RATANKBA)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MoleNet
Software description: [MoleNet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0553) is a downloader tool with backdoor capabilities that has been observed in use since at least 2019.(Citation: Cybereason Molerats Dec 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BlackCat
Software description: [BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) is ransomware written in Rust that has been offered via the Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) model. First observed November 2021, [BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) has been used to target multiple sectors and organizations in various countries and regions in Africa, the Americas, Asia, Australia, and Europe.(Citation: Microsoft BlackCat Jun 2022)(Citation: Sophos BlackCat Jul 2022)(Citation: ACSC BlackCat Apr 2022)
Platforms: Linux, Windows

Software name: NotPetya
Software description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) in a worldwide attack starting on June 27, 2017. While [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) appears as a form of ransomware, its main purpose was to destroy data and disk structures on compromised systems; the attackers never intended to make the encrypted data recoverable. As such, [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) may be more appropriately thought of as a form of wiper malware. [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploits EternalBlue and EternalRomance.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)(Citation: ESET Telebots June 2017)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HALFBAKED
Software description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) is a malware family consisting of multiple components intended to establish persistence in victim networks. (Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)
Platforms: None

Software name: StoneDrill
Software description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against both Middle Eastern and European targets in association with [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064).(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remexi
Software description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) is a Windows-based Trojan that was developed in the C programming language.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Snip3
Software description: [Snip3](https://attack.mitre

entities.name: WANNACRY
entities.description: WannaCry is ransomware that first appeared in a global attack in May 2017, affecting over 150 countries and utilizing the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue to spread across networks.

entities.name: EKANS
entities.description: EKANS is a ransomware variant written in Golang, first seen in December 2019, targeting sectors like energy and healthcare, causing significant operational disruptions.

entities.name: RATANKBA
entities.description: RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by the Lazarus Group, targeting financial institutions and various organizations across multiple countries.

entities.name: MOLENET
entities.description: MoleNet is a downloader tool with backdoor capabilities, observed in use since at least 2019.

entities.name: BLACKCAT
entities.description: BlackCat is ransomware written in Rust, first observed in November 2021, offered via Ransomware-as-a-Service and targeting multiple sectors globally.

entities.name: NOTPETYA
entities.description: NotPetya is malware used by the Sandworm Team in a worldwide attack starting June 27, 2017, primarily aimed at destroying data rather than ransom.

entities.name: HALFBAKED
entities.description: HALFBAKED is a malware family designed to establish persistence in victim networks, consisting of multiple components.

entities.name: STONEDRILL
entities.description: StoneDrill is wiper malware associated with APT33, discovered in campaigns against Middle Eastern and European targets.

entities.name: REMEXI
entities.description: Remexi is a Windows-based Trojan developed in C programming language.

entities.name: SANDWORM TEAM
entities.description: Sandworm Team is a hacking group associated with the Russian military, known for deploying NotPetya malware in a global attack.

entities.name: APT33
entities.description: APT33 is a cyber espionage group linked to Iran, known for its destructive campaigns using malware like StoneDrill.

target="BLACKCAT">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">EKANS and BlackCat are both ransomware variants that target various sectors and have been involved in significant operational disruptions.</data>      <data key="d5">fe9ae5fe3f72a886b62764bb50bc50e9</data>    </edge>    <edge source="RATANKBA" target="BLACKCAT">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">RATANKBA and BlackCat are both tools used in cyber attacks targeting financial institutions and other organizations across different countries.</data>      <data key="d5">fe9ae5fe3f72a886b62764bb50bc50e9</data>    </edge>    <edge source="RATANKBA" target="LAZARUS GROUP">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">RATANKBA is a remote controller tool specifically used by the Lazarus Group in their cyber attacks.</data>      <data key="d5">fe9ae5fe3f72a886b62764bb50bc50e9</data>    </edge>    <edge source="NOTPETYA" target="STONEDRILL">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">StoneDrill and NotPetya are both types of malware associated with destructive campaigns against targets in various regions.</data>      <data key="d5">fe9ae5fe3f72a886b62764bb50bc50e9</data>    </edge>    <edge source="NOTPETYA" target="SANDWORM TEAM">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">NotPetya was deployed by the Sandworm Team in a worldwide attack, causing significant damage to systems.</data>      <data key="d5">fe9ae5fe3f72a886b62764bb50bc50e9</data>    </edge>    <edge source="STONEDRILL" target="APT33">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">StoneDrill is associated with APT33, which has used it in campaigns against targets in the Middle East and Europe.</data>      <data key="d5">fe9ae5fe3f72a886b62764bb50bc50e9</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remexi
Software description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) is a Windows-based Trojan that was developed in the C programming language.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Snip3
Software description: [Snip3](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1086) is a sophisticated crypter-as-a-service that has been used since at least 2021 to obfuscate and load numerous strains of malware including [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087), [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379), [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), and [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198).(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FELIXROOT
Software description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) is a backdoor that has been used to target Ukrainian victims. (Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Olympic Destroyer
Software description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) against the 2018 Winter Olympics, held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The main purpose of the malware was to render infected computer systems inoperable. The malware leverages various native Windows utilities and API calls to carry out its destructive tasks. [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) has worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network in order to maximize its destructive impact.(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HermeticWizard
Software description: [HermeticWizard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0698) is a worm that has been used to spread [HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) in attacks against organizations in Ukraine since at least 2022.(Citation: ESET Hermetic Wizard March 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HELLOKITTY
Software description: [HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617) is a ransomware written in C++  that shares similar code structure and functionality with [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) and [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618). [HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617) has been used since at least 2020, targets have included a Polish video game developer and a Brazilian electric power company.(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: IcedID
Software description: [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information that has been observed in the wild since at least 2017.  [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483)  has been downloaded by [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) in multiple campaigns.(Citation: IBM IcedID November 2017)(Citation: Juniper IcedID June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: REvil
Software description: [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) is a ransomware family that has been linked to the [GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) group and operated as ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) since at least April 2019. [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496), which as been used against organizations in the manufacturing, transportation, and electric sectors, is highly configurable and shares code similarities with the GandCrab RaaS.(Citation: Secureworks REvil September 2019)(Citation: Intel 471 REvil March 2020)(Citation: Group IB Ransomware May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Astaroth
Software description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) is a Trojan and information stealer known to affect companies in Europe, Brazil, and throughout Latin America. It has been known publicly since at least late 2017. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)(Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)(Citation: Securelist Brazilian Banking Malware July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DarkTortilla
Software description: [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter that has been possibly active since at least August 2015. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cob

entities.name: REMEXI
entities.description: Remexi is a Windows-based Trojan developed in the C programming language, used for malicious purposes.

entities.name: SNIP3
entities.description: Snip3 is a sophisticated crypter-as-a-service used to obfuscate and load various strains of malware since at least 2021.

entities.name: FELIXROOT
entities.description: FELIXROOT is a backdoor malware that has targeted Ukrainian victims.

entities.name: OLYMPIC DESTROYER
entities.description: Olympic Destroyer is malware used by Sandworm Team against the 2018 Winter Olympics to render infected systems inoperable.

entities.name: HERMETICWIZARD
entities.description: HermeticWizard is a worm used to spread HermeticWiper in attacks against organizations in Ukraine since at least 2022.

entities.name: HELLOKITTY
entities.description: HELLOKITTY is a ransomware that has been used since at least 2020, targeting various organizations including a Polish video game developer and a Brazilian electric power company.

entities.name: ICEDID
entities.description: IcedID is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information, observed in the wild since at least 2017.

entities.name: REVIL
entities.description: REvil is a ransomware family linked to the GOLD SOUTHFIELD group, operating as ransomware-as-a-service since at least April 2019.

entities.name: ASTAROTH
entities.description: Astaroth is a Trojan and information stealer known to affect companies in Europe, Brazil, and Latin America since at least late 2017.

entities.name: DARK TORTILLA
entities.description: DarkTortilla is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter used to deliver various malware payloads since at least August 2015.

entities.description: Intel 471 is a cybersecurity intelligence company that provides insights into cyber threats and criminal activities.

entities.name: GROUP IB
entities.description: Group-IB is a cybersecurity company specializing in threat intelligence and incident response services.

entities.description: ESET is a global cybersecurity company known for its antivirus and anti-malware solutions.

entities.description: Telefonica is a telecommunications company that also provides cybersecurity services and solutions.

[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks DarkTortilla Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SVCReady
Software description: [SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) is a loader that has been used since at least April 2022 in malicious spam campaigns. Security researchers have noted overlaps between [TA551](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0127) activity and [SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) distribution, including similarities in file names, lure images, and identical grammatical errors.(Citation: HP SVCReady Jun 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Black Basta
Software description: [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered within the ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) model since at least April 2022; there are variants that target Windows and VMWare ESXi servers. [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) operations have included the double extortion technique where in addition to demanding ransom for decrypting the files of targeted organizations the cyber actors also threaten to post sensitive information to a leak site if the ransom is not paid. [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) affiliates have targeted multiple high-value organizations, with the largest number of victims based in the U.S. Based on similarities in TTPs, leak sites, payment sites, and negotiation tactics, security researchers assess the [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) RaaS operators could include current or former members of the [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) group.(Citation: Palo Alto Networks Black Basta August 2022)(Citation: Deep Instinct Black Basta August 2022)(Citation: Minerva Labs Black Basta May 2022)(Citation: Avertium Black Basta June 2022)(Citation: NCC Group Black Basta June 2022)(Citation: Cyble Black Basta May 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Avaddon
Software description: [Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered as Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) since at least June 2020.(Citation: Awake Security Avaddon)(Citation: Arxiv Avaddon Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Octopus
Software description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) is a Windows Trojan written in the Delphi programming language that has been used by [Nomadic Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0133) to target government organizations in Central Asia since at least 2014.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)(Citation: Security Affairs DustSquad Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Nomadic Octopus 2018) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HOPLIGHT
Software description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) is a backdoor Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PyDCrypt
Software description: [PyDCrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1032) is malware written in Python designed to deliver [DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033). It has been used by [Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) since at least September 2021, with each sample tailored for its intended victim organization.(Citation: Checkpoint MosesStaff Nov 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Maze
Software description: [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) ransomware, previously known as "ChaCha", was discovered in May 2019. In addition to encrypting files on victim machines for impact, [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) operators conduct information stealing campaigns prior to encryption and post the information online to extort affected companies.(Citation: FireEye Maze May 2020)(Citation: McAfee Maze March 2020)(Citation: Sophos Maze VM September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DEATHRANSOM
Software description: [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) is ransomware written in C that has been used since at least 2020, and has potential overlap with [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) and [HELLOKITTY](https://attack

entities.name: NANOCORE

entities.name: REDLINE

entities.name: COBALT STRIKE
entities.description: Cobalt Strike is a tool that has been delivered by Dark Tortilla.

entities.name: METASPLOIT
entities.description: Metasploit is a penetration testing framework that has been delivered by Dark Tortilla.

entities.name: SVCREADY
entities.description: SVCReady is a loader used in malicious spam campaigns since at least April 2022, with overlaps in activity with TA551.

entities.name: DARKWATCHMAN
entities.description: DarkWatchman is a lightweight JavaScript-based RAT first observed in November 2021.

entities.name: BLACK BASTA
entities.description: Black Basta is ransomware offered as a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) since at least April 2022, known for double extortion techniques.

entities.name: AVADDON
entities.description: Avaddon is ransomware offered as Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) since at least June 2020.

entities.name: OCTOPUS
entities.description: Octopus is a Windows Trojan used by Nomadic Octopus to target government organizations in Central Asia since at least 2014.

entities.name: HOPLIGHT
entities.description: HOPLIGHT is a backdoor Trojan reportedly used by the North Korean government.

entities.name: PYDCRYPT
entities.description: PyDCrypt is malware written in Python used to deliver DCSrv, tailored for its intended victim organization since at least September 2021.

entities.name: MAZE

entities.name: DEATHRANSOM

entities.name: NOMADIC OCTOPUS

entities.description: HELLOKITTY is another ransomware that has potential overlap with DEATHRANSOM, indicating similarities in tactics and techniques.

Platforms: Windows

Software name: DEATHRANSOM
Software description: [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) is ransomware written in C that has been used since at least 2020, and has potential overlap with [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) and [HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617).(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BADHATCH
Software description: [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) is a backdoor that has been utilized by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) since at least 2019. [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) has been used to target the insurance, retail, technology, and chemical industries in the United States, Canada, South Africa, Panama, and Italy.(Citation: Gigamon BADHATCH Jul 2019)(Citation: BitDefender BADHATCH Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ursnif
Software description: [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) is a banking trojan and variant of the Gozi malware observed being spread through various automated exploit kits, [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001)s, and malicious links.(Citation: NJCCIC Ursnif Sept 2016)(Citation: ProofPoint Ursnif Aug 2016) [Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) is associated primarily with data theft, but variants also include components (backdoors, spyware, file injectors, etc.) capable of a wide variety of behaviors.(Citation: TrendMicro Ursnif Mar 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: SharpStage
Software description: [SharpStage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0546) is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.(Citation: Cybereason Molerats Dec 2020)(Citation: BleepingComputer Molerats Dec 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Micropsia
Software description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) is a remote access tool written in Delphi.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bazar
Software description: [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) is a downloader and backdoor that has been used since at least April 2020, with infections primarily against professional services, healthcare, manufacturing, IT, logistics and travel companies across the US and Europe. [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) reportedly has ties to [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) campaigns and can be used to deploy additional malware, including ransomware, and to steal sensitive data.(Citation: Cybereason Bazar July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Netwalker
Software description: [Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457) is fileless ransomware written in PowerShell and executed directly in memory.(Citation: TrendMicro Netwalker May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KOMPROGO
Software description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is a signature backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) that is capable of process, file, and registry management. (Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476

entities.name: DEATHRANSOM
entities.description: DEATHRANSOM is ransomware written in C that has been used since at least 2020, with potential overlap with other malware like FIVEHANDS and HELLOKITTY.

entities.name: BADHATCH
entities.description: BADHATCH is a backdoor utilized by FIN8 since at least 2019, targeting various industries in multiple countries.

entities.name: URSNIF
entities.description: URSNIF is a banking trojan and variant of the Gozi malware, primarily associated with data theft and capable of various malicious behaviors.

entities.name: COBALT STRIKE
entities.description: COBALT STRIKE is a commercial remote access tool designed for adversary simulation and executing targeted attacks.

entities.name: SHARPSTAGE
entities.description: SHARPSTAGE is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.

entities.name: QAKBOT
entities.description: QAKBOT is a modular banking trojan used by financially-motivated actors, evolving from an information stealer to a ransomware delivery agent.

entities.name: MICROPSIA
entities.description: MICROPSIA is a remote access tool written in Delphi.

entities.name: BAZAR
entities.description: BAZAR is a downloader and backdoor used since at least April 2020, targeting various sectors and capable of deploying additional malware.

entities.name: NETWALKER
entities.description: NETWALKER is fileless ransomware written in PowerShell, executed directly in memory.

entities.name: KOMPROGO
entities.description: KOMPROGO is a signature backdoor used by APT32, capable of process, file, and registry management.

entities.name: HELLOKITTY
entities.description: HELLOKITTY is another type of ransomware that has potential overlap with DEATHRANSOM, suggesting a connection in their functionalities.

entities.name: APT32
entities.description: APT32 is a threat actor group known for using KOMPROGO, indicating its role in cyber attacks.

chunk:
KOMPROGO
Software description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is a signature backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) that is capable of process, file, and registry management. (Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EVILNUM
Software description: [EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) is fully capable backdoor that was first identified in 2018. [EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) is used by the APT group [Evilnum](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0120) which has the same name.(Citation: ESET EvilNum July 2020)(Citation: Prevailion EvilNum May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: CharmPower
Software description: [CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) is a PowerShell-based, modular backdoor that has been used by [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) since at least 2022.(Citation: Check Point APT35 CharmPower January 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kazuar
Software description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework. (Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: Lucifer
Software description: [Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) is a crypto miner and DDoS hybrid malware that leverages well-known exploits to spread laterally on Windows platforms.(Citation: Unit 42 Lucifer June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GravityRAT
Software description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) is a remote access tool (RAT) and has been in ongoing development since 2016. The actor behind the tool remains unknown, but two usernames have been recovered that link to the author, which are "TheMartian" and "The Invincible." According to the National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India, the malware has been identified in attacks against organization and entities in India. (Citation: Talos GravityRAT)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay. Their names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 
* Filter Network Traffic 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning is an attack technique that exploits vulnerabilities in network protocols to intercept and manipulate network traffic.

entities.name: SMB RELAY
entities.description: SMB Relay is an attack technique that allows an attacker to intercept and relay authentication requests to gain unauthorized access to network resources.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: This mitigation method involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: This mitigation method uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: This mitigation method involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources, using physical and logical segmentation to enhance security.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: This mitigation method uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering to secure network communications.

entities.name: NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Network traffic refers to the data that is transmitted over a network, which can be filtered to enhance security.

entities.name: INTRUSION DETECTION SIGNATURES
entities.description: Intrusion detection signatures are predefined patterns used to identify and block malicious network traffic.

entities.name: VIRTUAL PRIVATE CLOUD (VPC)
entities.description: A Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) is a secure and isolated section of a cloud provider's infrastructure that allows users to run resources in a virtualized environment.

entities.name: DE-MILITARIZED ZONE (DMZ)
entities.description: A De-Militarized Zone (DMZ) is a physical or logical subnetwork that contains and exposes an organization's external-facing services to an untrusted network, typically the internet.

There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called DHCP Spoofing. Their names are as follows:
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering, configuring software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to strategies or techniques employed to reduce or eliminate the impact of specific attack techniques, such as DHCP Spoofing.

There are 24 software using the attack technique called Archive via Utility. Their names are as follows:
* certutil
* PoshC2
* Pupy
* Rclone
* Crutch
* Okrum
* ccf32
* InvisiMole
* DustySky
* Daserf

* IceApple
* iKitten
* WindTail
* CORALDECK
* Micropsia
* Octopus
* OopsIE
* Calisto
* PowerShower
* AppleSeed
* PoetRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: certutil
Software description: [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) is a command-line utility that can be used to obtain certificate authority information and configure Certificate Services. (Citation: TechNet Certutil)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Rclone
Software description: [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) is a command line program for syncing files with cloud storage services such as Dropbox, Google Drive, Amazon S3, and MEGA. [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) has been used in a number of ransomware campaigns, including those associated with the [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) and DarkSide Ransomware-as-a-Service operations.(Citation: Rclone)(Citation: Rclone Wars)(Citation: Detecting Rclone)(Citation: DarkSide Ransomware Gang)(Citation: DFIR Conti Bazar Nov 2021)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: Crutch
Software description: [Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) is a backdoor designed for document theft that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2015.(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Okrum
Software description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004).(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ccf32
Software description: [ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) is data collection malware that has been used since at least February 2019, most notably during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign; there is also a similar x64 version.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: InvisiMole
Software description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) is a modular spyware program that has been used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013. [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has two backdoor modules called RC2FM and RC2CL that are used to perform post-exploitation activities. It has been discovered on compromised victims in the Ukraine and Russia. [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) infrastructure has been used to download and execute [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) against a small number of victims.(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2018)(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DustySky
Software description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) is multi-stage malware written in .NET that has been used by [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) since May 2015. (Citation: DustySky) (Citation:

iMole June 2018)(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DustySky
Software description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) is multi-stage malware written in .NET that has been used by [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) since May 2015. (Citation: DustySky) (Citation: DustySky2)(Citation: Kaspersky MoleRATs April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Daserf
Software description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) is a backdoor that has been used to spy on and steal from Japanese, South Korean, Russian, Singaporean, and Chinese victims. Researchers have identified versions written in both Visual C and Delphi. (Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017) (Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PUNCHBUGGY
Software description: [PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196) is a backdoor malware used by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) that has been observed targeting POS networks in the hospitality industry. (Citation: Morphisec ShellTea June 2019)(Citation: FireEye Fin8 May 2016) (Citation: FireEye Know Your Enemy FIN8 Aug 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ramsay
Software description: [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) is an information stealing malware framework designed to collect and exfiltrate sensitive documents, including from air-gapped systems. Researchers have identified overlaps between [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) and the [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012)-associated Retro malware.(Citation: Eset Ramsay May 2020)(Citation: Antiy CERT Ramsay April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Turian
Software description: [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is a backdoor that has been used by [BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) to target Ministries of Foreign Affairs, telecommunication companies, and charities in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. First reported in 2021, [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is likely related to Quarian, an older backdoor that was last observed being used in 2013 against diplomatic targets in Syria and the United States.(Citation: ESET BackdoorDiplomacy Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: IceApple
Software description: [IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022) is a modular Internet Information Services (IIS) post-exploitation framework, that has been used since at least 2021 against the technology, academic, and government sectors.(Citation: CrowdStrike IceApple May 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: iKitten
Software description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) is a macOS exfiltration agent  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: WindTail
Software description: [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) is a macOS surveillance implant used by [Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112). [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) shares code similarities with Hack Back aka KitM OSX.(Citation: SANS Windshift August 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail1 dec 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail2 jan 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: CORALDECK
Software description: [CORALDECK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0212) is an exfiltration tool used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067). (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Micropsia
Software description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) is a remote access tool written in Delphi.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Octopus
Software description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) is a Windows Trojan written in the Delphi programming language that has been used by [Nomadic Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0133) to target government organizations in Central Asia since at least 2014.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)(Citation: Security Affairs DustSquad Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Nomadic Octopus 2018) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: OopsIE
Software description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) is a Trojan used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) to remotely execute commands as well as upload/download files to/from victims. (Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Calisto
Software description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274)

chunk:
: OopsIE
Software description: [OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) is a Trojan used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) to remotely execute commands as well as upload/download files to/from victims. (Citation: Unit 42 OopsIE! Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Calisto
Software description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is a macOS Trojan that opens a backdoor on the compromised machine. [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is believed to have first been developed in 2016. (Citation: Securelist Calisto July 2018) (Citation: Symantec Calisto July 2018)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: PowerShower
Software description: [PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [Inception](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0100) for initial reconnaissance and to download and execute second stage payloads.(Citation: Unit 42 Inception November 2018)(Citation: Kaspersky Cloud Atlas August 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AppleSeed
Software description: [AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) is a backdoor that has been used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) to target South Korean government, academic, and commercial  targets since at least 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Kimsuky June 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: PoetRAT
Software description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that was first identified in April 2020. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has been used in multiple campaigns against the private and public sectors in Azerbaijan, including ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector. The STIBNITE activity group has been observed using the malware. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) derived its name from references in the code to poet William Shakespeare. (Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)(Citation: Talos PoetRAT October 2020)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: OopsIE is a Trojan used by OilRig to remotely execute commands and manage files on victims' machines.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a cyber threat group that utilizes OopsIE for malicious activities.

entities.name: CALISTO
entities.description: Calisto is a macOS Trojan that opens a backdoor on compromised machines, believed to have been developed in 2016.

entities.name: POWERSHOWER
entities.description: PowerShower is a PowerShell backdoor used by Inception for reconnaissance and executing payloads.

entities.name: INCEPTION
entities.description: Inception is a cyber threat group that employs PowerShower for its operations.

entities.name: APPLESEED
entities.description: AppleSeed is a backdoor used by Kimsuky to target South Korean government and commercial entities since at least 2021.

entities.name: KIMSUKY
entities.description: Kimsuky is a cyber threat group known for targeting South Korean institutions using AppleSeed.

entities.name: POETRAT
entities.description: PoetRAT is a remote access trojan identified in April 2020, used in campaigns against various sectors in Azerbaijan.

entities.name: STIBNITE
entities.description: STIBNITE is an activity group that has been observed using PoetRAT in its operations.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform on which Calisto operates.

entities.name: ANDROID
entities.description: Android is an operating system platform on which AppleSeed operates.

chunk:
There are 7 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle. Their names are as follows:
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* User Training 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is an attack technique that involves intercepting and altering communication between two parties without their knowledge.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information with strong encryption.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a mitigation method that prevents access to file shares and remote systems, using mechanisms like network concentrators and RDP gateways.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method that educates users about access or manipulation attempts to reduce risks from spearphishing and social engineering.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: Network Segmentation is a mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems and prevent access to sensitive information.

* RotaJakiro
